reviewText:
In short i spend 2600 hours in this game (2 years) and never regret buying and playing it
-Awesome game, awesome campaign!!
-Brings WH40K to life
-Buy it if you love tactical RTS or just a WH40K fan...its totaly worth it

The Long Version~

Welp been a fan of WH40k for awile now and still is. As you can see the 2600 hours that i played this was one of the longest games i played and if you like more tactical and up close RTS rather than mass production and watching everything explode, then this game is for you.

In my opinion they also improved alot of the Warhammer 40K models/characters to look more badass, Space marines look more heavy/bulky and...well they just made every faction look more believable and cool looking compared to DOW1

In terms of following lore they did try their best and improved alot compared to DOW1. but really how can you balance things in a legit game when 1 Marine has the potential to take out a small army in lore wise

Its a good game.
voteText: 127 of 142 people (89%) found this review helpful 19 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Most people know what this game is about. The store page is pretty accurate in describing what it is.

Is it good?
Depends. Some people enjoy making a massive army and steam rolling the enemy. Others enjoy having a smaller amount of units and managing them using their unique abilities. If you fall into the second of these two, then give this game a go. If you prefer large armies, I'd say pass on this.

The Warhammer 40k universe is incredibly well presented in this game. The gameplay is mostly focused on smaller squads and managing their abilities. The combat is great with it's array of animations (which you can catch repeating a little too often sometimes) and solid sounds to back it up.

The single player campaign is good, although I think most people will be attracted to the multiplayer more than the campaign.

What I would add to this game if I could would be to add more races (I miss Tau and Necrons) and have more maps to play on.

A solid buy if you enjoyed previous DoW games. Just be aware it does differ from the first and although the addition of Tyranids is awesome, they've left out other races.
voteText: 92 of 98 people (94%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
3 Awesome and largley different game modes

Campaign > control 4 squads, level up, find better Loot. You arent stuck with the same 4 squads either as they can be swapped for others ( dont like Scout marines, no problem, Dreadnaught?), some interesting boss battles aswell.

Last Stand > 3 player controlled heros must survive against hordes of enemies, 20 waves with special boss waves, fight the Eldar , Space Marines, Imperials, Tyranids , Orks and Chaos. Level each Hero to 20, unlocking more gear as you level, Play as An ork Mek Boy, Space Marine, or Eldar Farseer.

Multiplayer PVP or Ai > Small scale warfare heavily focused on tactics and stratergy, an example of what it can be like is 'Avatar of Khaine is very strong but a good opponent could kill him with a handful of troops if he isnt supported', each race can choose between 3 commanders, eldar for example can have a Seer Council Warlock, Farseer or Warp spider commander, Each commander has its own wargear to purchase in game.

All modes are enjoyable, and the game is very well made with a great ammount of detail for an RTS, that being said , last stand and campaign double up as RPG games, I often feel like playing them if I want a change from Torchlight 2 or something similar.  9/10 would highly recommend.

- Con - more could have been done for people who play the game offline, a lot of newer games seem to be very restricting to people who don't want to be online, this is no exception, although The campaign and PvsAI alone is solid enough to merit its very reasonable price tag.

reviewText:
Dawn of War II is a science-fiction real time strategy game based in the Warhammer 40k universe.

When most people think of RTS games, games such as Starcraft and Warcraft typically come to mind. You have workers to build up your base so that you can train more powerful soldiers. Resources must be harvested, but there is a finite amount of them. Indeed, this is how the first Dawn of War functioned.  However, the sequel takes a much different approach.

In the single player campaign, you are given 6 unique squads, and 6 only, to take on missions. No base building whatsoever. These squads can be upgraded with weapons and armour, and can level up to gain bonus abilities. It is a extremely well-executed combination of an rpg and a rts. The story is fairly linear, but you are free to explore the planets and do side missions at your realative leisure (that is, until the space bugs show up. Then you need to be quick or else the bugs will eat the planet).

The multiplayer is also a genre-masher. Each race has three different heroes" which act similarily to champions in DotA or LoL. They level up
recommended: and can oftentimes turn the tide of a battle. All of your other units are spawned from you one and only building
hoursPlayed: so if it dies you're out of luck. There aren't any workers
voteText: and you must collect resources by capping points. A capped point will grant you the resource constantly. The more points you have
helpfulPercent: the more resources you'll consistently obtain.\n\nThe other huge change in DoW II is the "Last Stand" game mode. Three players
votesHelpful: each controlling one of the heroes
votesTotal: must survive wave after wave of enemies (top-down horde mode pretty much). You're heroes level up
votesFunny: get more powerful
commentsCount: and eventually die because Last Stand is hard.\n\nIf you enjoy RTS games
column16: but are tired of the same-old same-old style that most RTS's follow
column17: then I would recommend this game (or DoW II: Retribution the stand-alone sequel)."
column21: 63 of 67 people (94%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
When Dawn of War II came out, it was an absolutely groundbreaking title. It offered some of the most competitive multiplayer at the time, and the later addition of The Last Stand mode offered hours of entertainment to both casual gamers and pro-players alike.

Now, if in 2015 the size of the multiplayer community has dwindled only to a fraction of what it was, you can still find other players out there (steam forums help in this regard) and enjoy some good games, or just plunge straight through the campaign.

Dawn of War II was worth every cent at the time it was released. As part of a Steam Sale, however, there's no reason for you not to pick this up and give it a go. Especially if you're already  fan of the first Dawn of War, or just appreciate the universe of Warhammer 40,000 in general.

reviewText: This is one of my favorite games I highly recommend it! The campaign is very good and engaging, you can also do coop campaign with a buddy, 2 squads per person! The visuals are very good and so is the sound quality, if you have a good sound system or high quality headphones it really stands out! With the removal of horrid GFWL and achievement integration to steamworks new life has been brought to the game! Theres also Multiplayer and Last Stand! Both highly recommended after a run through the main campaign. If you like Company of Heroes type RTS games and/or are a fan of Warhammer Universe I highly recommend this game!

reviewText:
I'm a big fan of Warhammer 40k and strategy games so I couldn't miss this one. Story isn't much entertaining in this Dawn of war II series, but the gameplay where you lead 4 units and use tactics in order to defeat your foes (orcs, eldars, chaos, tiranids) who highly outnumber your forces is much more challenging and enjoyable. Game offers you coop option in campaign, where each of you controls two units, this is huge plus for DoW II, makes it even better and also playable on master difficulty.

Game has few multiplayer mods, but with only a few players playing this game, its almost impossible to start MP match. At least some people still play The Last Stand mode, which is for me the best part of this game, 3 players in the arena fighting against enemies wave by wave. i think this game was meant to be played mainly in multiplayer but it didn't work that way.

I recommend this especially for its coop campaign, worth to give it a try.

7.5 / 10

reviewText: If you're new to the DoW fanchise you might like it, but if you're a returning player ehhh...\nThe game is in no way bad, but if you've played the previous DoW games(Dawn of War, Winter Assault, Dark Crusade and Soulstorm) you most likely won't want to waste your money. I've been playing DoW since 2005 so I've grown very fond of the franchise, but this game and all of the titles after it have killed the series for me. They have gotten rid of the base-building mechanics completely; something that I thought defined the DoW franchise. It feels too empty for me to play anymore, maybe one day they'll bring back base-building...

reviewText:
While fun this game doesn't manage to hold my interest like Dawn of War Dark Crusade or Soulstorm. I am also loathe to call it an RTS because it departs from all of the core bits of that game type. There is no base construction at all, or unit construction. What it DOES do well is act more like a real time adaptation of the tabletop game. You command 4 squads on a map to take on various objective. Which squads you take are up to you, within the ones the game makes available, and you can go after 1 optional objective per run. Missions are scored by how you do on several factors, the better you do overall the more XP your squads get. As you level up your squads you can customize their skills and gear. The story is fairly engaging and the voice acting doesn't suck, but also feels like they tried to appeal to a more generic audience than a hardcore Warhammer 40k fan.

Really it feels more like strategy roleplaying game and less real time strategy.  3 out 5 stars imo. Definitely worth it on sale.

reviewText:
This the review of the righteous! Fear its divine power!

If you're looking for incredibly zealous outcries to inspire your daily actions, then this is the game for you. Dawn of War II is the sequel to the original Dawn of War and all its expansions and it delivers in spades.

For starters, this game is built on the rich lore and backstory of the Warhammer universe. After their disasterous defeat on Kaurava, the Blood Ravens are down to but a single star sytem from where to recruit their new members to fight in the Holy Emperor's name. One problem; the Tyrannids are coming and they have an appetite for planets and everything that lives on it. You control the Force Commander. A nameless, and voiceless avatar who leads a small taskforce from planet to planet to stop the Hive Fleet before it devours the precious planets of the aurelia system.

Contrary to the original Dawn of War, this game is focussed on tactics rather than strategy and plays out on a much smaller scale. Instead of base building and massing armies you control up to four units, each with their own abilities and weapons. The game also introduces an RPG element that allows you to customise your squads with new armour, weapons and other items to smite the enemies of man.

It is therefore such a shame that there is only one campaign to play. This game offers four different races to play as, but does not allow you to play them in the same narrative context as the space marines. That said, this game's campaign is no slouch. It is a fully realised story with stellar voice acting accross the board. If brawny men with zealous convictions are not your thing, then you better pass on this pack of awesomeness. Unfortunately for you, there are no other reasons to not get it, so what are you waiting for?

reviewText:
A lot of things have improved from the original Dawn of War. Now the UI is cleaner. You can easily navigate around during the heat of the missions.

The only minor grip is that you can't really hear the voice acting too well during the mist of a heavy firefight. What's funny is that once the battle is over with it goes from low sound to high sound in an almost instant. There is also the issue of lack of saves unlike the original one. This game offers online co-op which is cool. The details are much more improved since the last game. Although, some of the last game's mechanics seem to be more needed" here rather than just the one game.

All in all it's a good Warhammer game."

reviewText:
I thought it wouldn't be as good as the old one... it wasn't, it really really wasn't.
I PERSONALLY found the story kinda of boring and the gameplay dull, the guns had no real impact and the repeditive nature of the maps for every missions was nearly the same, kill all the enemies then go after the boss and it took to long, Xcom knew how to do squad combat.
It also pushes a story that is hard to care about, the same could be said about the characters that it tries so hard to push on you.
It does have interesting defensive missions but that the only time where the game came to life for me. However, the resources you where defending where completely usuless to the actual gameplay, the arena was an interesting idea but I didn't care for it.
I missed the base building where you could create an army where you could actually flank and use actual army tactics, yes the old one had its mistakes but it actually felt like you could build an amry and have massive, exciting battles. Even in the skirmish mode where you are meant to build armys it takes far to long and the battle generally goes back and forth and comes off as boring, with no obvious units that are clearly meant to be used agaist others and even the ones that are useless for the task they were intented for. The campaign in no way prepares you for skirmishers and multiplayer with completely different rules appling for the each type of game mode, I know there are meant to be differences but I feel that there is too big of a gap and so puts people off playing the other game modes.
So yea over all point, this is not the amry building game that it claims to be, expect small squad combat that is slow and tedious where you mircomanage your squad. You can do better than this game, my advise play the older one, as I said before they have plenty of mistakes but are a hell of a lot more fun.
voteText: 46 of 71 people (65%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Dawn Of War II is easily one of the best real time strategy games out there. For me personally, it easily beats Starcraft 2, as far as the singleplayer mode is concerned, though. It has a brilliant mix of strategy and light RPG elements that all work together quite nicely. Find some random loot, give it to one of your units and you're all set to kill those damn orcs. It adds a certain layer of personalization. Plus, there's quite some loot to be found so there's always an incentive to explore the levels.

The levels are set up with a cover system. Green means you get the best cover for your squad and yellow is 50/50. You actually have to set up your units carefully and not rush them towards the objectives. They'll only get killed. You *have* to use the cover properly in order to survive some of the tougher levels. Some of these levels even end with a bossfight, which are epic and awesome, even if they're not all that focused on strategy, but more on action.

The graphics are, even to this day, beautiful and colorful. Just don't zoom in too much. The voice acting is also still solid.

Now the story I can't remember so that hasn't made such an impression on me. But I admire this game for trying to bring new stuff to the strategy genre. It was really in need of some new and fresh ideas. Relic has done this beautifully.

About the multiplayer; I must admit that I haven't really given that a shot, but the survival mode is addictive and hard. I've played that for hours and never once got bored. I don't think any other game before Dawn Of War II has ever introduced that, for the RTS genre that is.

As of this day I'm still waiting for that Dawn Of War III announcement. Just don't make the same mistake as with Company Of Heroes 2, Relic. Make it refreshing and new once more, just like you did with this gem of a game.

Highly recommended !

[Rating: 92/100]

reviewText:
DOW 2.......

It's campaign I do like a lot. Likable characters, good level design, neat cinematics, great progression system but it's not the reason why im down voting this. Its multiplayer is flawed. Not only is it not balanced It's really just a MOBA in my opinion. You have a base which is a single building and if you loose that building you loose the game, you have your hero, and a few other controlable characters that you can build. the squads and vehicles you build, yes, they are the backbone of your force but not as valuable and frequent as the first game. When I play as Chaos (playing Retribution) I didnt build some huge army like in DOW 1 one most strat games, all I did was build 2 Chaos Space marine squad, 2 Heretic squads, an Unclean One, and upgrade my hero and I win. In DOW 1 you would throw up to MILLIONS of of Guardsmen, Cultists, Space Marines, Baneblades, ect untill one side fell giving me the Warhammer 40k vibe. This is just a skirmish of 25 soldiers and a fat man doing a drive by on 20 space marines and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on a 60,000 health building untill It blew up.

Im not saying this game is horrible and should die. I still find it fun, Its just that the first game is way better if you want a REAL RTS instead of a hybrid between Dota and DOW.

reviewText:
I've waited quite some time to play this game, first my older laptop couldnt run the game, then i bought my ps3 and ran out of money, finally steam had a great sale and i was able to fulfill my long waited dream. As huge fan of warhammer 40k, (since chaos gate, turn based game) and after playing dawn of war I and all the expansions DOW II met all my big expectations, the graphics are superb, the squad dynamics are awesome, and the pace is just right, the story is well written and has some interesting twists.

I loved the rpg aspect of the game, improving the loadouts and pursuing additional missions to get better items, the perk system is balanced and suits for every gamer's style.

On the negative end, sometimes during boss fights controlling all of your squads to avoid an aoe attack was quite impossible, the ai during formations was a little sloppy so if you moved all of your troops at once it looked like a circus rather than a marching army.

Hope this was useful to anyone out there interested in this games.

reviewText:
Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War II was pretty good. Unlike its predecessor, Dawn of War 1, the base building concept is thrown out the window with this one. Instead it's squad-based, like Company of Heroes for example, which happens to be a Relic game as well.

It ends up playing more like an Action RPG really, with you using the specific skills of each of your unique squadmates, each with their own personality and class, collecting new armor, weapons, to change up your playstyle as needed, and last but not least, leveling up and boosting your characters. Hell, even the boss fights keep you on your toes, with their own abilities having you to keep moving around in order to take as little damage as possible. I enjoyed that, and I also enjoyed Relic's streamlined approach to ye olde RTS.

And no, streamline does not an easier game make. It very much punished me for getting my priorities wrong when it came to focus fire on the wrong unit. Wasn't a complete cakewalk on Normal difficulty and I'm thankful for that. Though perhaps that could have been because I largely ignored the cover mechanic, which is strongly stressed in these games, yet seldomly did I feel the need to jump into cover.

Now Relic knows how to make good RTSes. Not only that, they also know how to give the amazing Warhammer 40k universe the epicness it rightfully deserves. Now I'm not too familiar with the 40k lore at all, but this game got me curious to want to learn more about it, because it just reeks of awesome. The voice acting's awesome, the music fits right into the mood, and the ambience and atmosphere is spot on.

The campaign mode isn't Starcraft 2's levels of inventiveness and non linearity, but it's not slouch either. You get all kinds of optional missions to do, special persistent buildings that you can capture that maintain passive bonuses for you throughout the game, that you have to keep defending every now and then against invaders. Though honestly, the missions do get a bit repetitive eventually, and by the end I just wanted to go to the ending and get it over with. Again, it's not because I found this a bad game, I liked it a lot, but I played the Campaign mode only, and RTS single player campaigns are hard to get right. While the old school RTSes didn't care at all about their level design, (build base, kill other guy's base, repeat) Dawn of War II at least gets points in effort for trying to mix it up.

As for the story itself, it was admittedly clichéd but again, the epicness of the Warhammer 40k universe is so compelling by itself that I actually want to get Chaos Rising and Retribution eventually just to see how it all unfolds. Dawn of War II was a nice ride, but not one I'd keep coming back to for more over and over again.

reviewText:
Didn't do it for me.  While I loved the first DoW, this one fell short.  Much more action/point-and-shoot than strategy of any kind.

The missions felt quite repetitive, especially towards the end of the game.  I won the last few missions by just selecting all 4 squads and right clicking enemies.  (Also, on the last mission you end up being able to control all 6 of your squads but can only see life bars for the first four?  What gives?)

There were SO many gear drops I felt like I spent more time sorting thru junk to find the best weapons and armor than I spent time in actual missions.

As other reviews mention, the plot/voice-acting is kinda 'meh'.  Some of the dialogue/arguing between your squad captains after the last few missions seems especially pointless.

I can't comment on the multiplayer as I haven't tried it and likely won't.

I feel the first game just had a lot more strategy and was more of a challenge.

reviewText:
The Dawn of War 2 (and Chaos Rising as it is really an extension of Dow2) campaign is great fun to play through with a friend in co-op. The missions are challenging, the atmosphere is great and the cutscenes really add to the atmosphere (and I am not a fan of cutscenes). Highly recommended. Plus Relic are definitely good guys when it comes to long term support.

Full marks to Relic for patching out the awful Games for Windows Live and replacing it with Steamworks. They did not have to, but chose to and for that I think they are very cool and it makes me far more likely to buy future games (Dawn of War 3 please!)

Dawn of War 2 is a really great adaptation of the 40k universe - it strips out the base building of Dawn of War 1 and focusses on small units and heroes, which is much closer to the fiction and the miniatures game. Some people did not like that, but I definitely did. You control up to 4 squads (or 2 squads each if you are playing co-op) and fight a variety of foes each of which benefit from different strategies of attack. There is also a larger meta-game element of controlling various resource sites and that works pretty well too.

All in all I highly rate Dawn of War 2 and Chaos Rising.

reviewText:
I've been playing the Warhammer 40k tabletop game since 2002 (originally with Space Wolves, now rolling with Word Bearers and Astra Militarum) and I loved the original Dawn of War. Dawn of War II has more in common with Relic's Company of Heroes series then it does the original Dawn of War, in single-player games anyways, as you are only in command of small groups of Space Marines. No massive armies of vehicles, fliers and Squiggoths in this one.

Despite the reduced scale, Dawn of War II is still one of the best squad-based RTS games available. The graphics still look good, the music is the typical epic" soundtrack and matches the grim dark setting. Control is perhaps the largest issue as it can be hard to get your squads to go into cover and it gets tough to pick out enemy characters.  Keyboard hotkeys help but it's still annoying.

All told
recommended: Dawn of War II is a great pick up if you want a small scale RTS or just a decent game in the 40k Universe."

reviewText: When I initially started playing Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II I felt disappointed - gone are massive armies, instead there is small-scale squad based combat; no base construction in the campaign - only minimal base management in multiplayer. This was not the Dawn of War I had grown to love over the years!\n\nIt took me some time to set aside my initial prejudices and really delve into the game. When I finally did, however, I discovered an amazingly deep, satisfying and addictive RTS game. The squad based nature of the game and customization options allow for a tactical depth that the first game only barely scratched the surface of, and the campaign missions are consistently entertaining. It's not better than Dawn of War I and its various expansions, nor is it worse - it's just a very different game, but one that is sure to please any fan Warhammer 40k.

reviewText: Dawn of War II is a very divisive game, it's really nothing like its prequel.  Somewhere between the two games, Relic released another stellar RTS (Company of Heroes) that fundamentally changed the way RTS games play; it was a game less focused on base building and throwing huge armies at each other, but more focused on advancing technology and tactical engagements.  Dawn of War II takes over from there, and iterates the formula into the 40K setting.  Gone are the micromanaged bases and huge armies of Dawn of War fighting Epic-like battles.  You will lead smaller and fewer squads and named heroes, with ability progression and customizable wargear, choose your battles on a campaign map, receive rewards/loot, customize your hero and ultimately stick it to the filthy Xenos.  Don't jump in expecting Starcraft/C&C type of RTS gameplay, keep an open mind, and you will be rewarded with an incredibly rewarding campaign experience leading the Blood Ravens and their familiar heroes to victory and salvation.  Dawn of War II has graphics that still measure up to this day, and its requirements should be a piece of cake for any modern system.  Its campaign coop is incredibly fun, so I strongly suggest that you nag a friend into buying it with you.  Final caveat: Do not buy it for its multiplayer; for that, buy the standalone expansion Dawn of War II: Retribution.

reviewText:
Having been completely obsessed with the first DoW game for years and putting in countless hours into online ranked and frantic base building and huge battles, DoW 2 came as a massive suprise to me. Although I prefer the first game, I can appreciate the change in direction and am enjoying the campaign so far.

I do feel this game is a little tedious at times (I find myself dipping into it for an hour and coming back another time) but maybe this is because, I feel, this is a game that is much more catered to a more casual approach rather than 50 minute, off the scale RTS stratergy battles.

Overall, seeing as I'd give DoW a 10/10, I feel DoW 2 deserves a 6.5. It's quite fun and the customising of your commanders is cool, but I feel like once I've completed the campaign they'll be little in the way to keep me coming back for more.

Here's to DoW3 and the return of base building. Hurrah!

reviewText:
This is Dawn of War II, while I do recommend this game, bare in mind it is NOT like its predecessor, I would call Dawn of  War a classical RTS with a base-capture element, while this is more of a action-oriented tactical RPG with more units. The Campaign is the best mode in my opinion or the online area modes and you won't be constructing buildings at all, all you will do in the regular 1 vs 1 mode is producing units. Controlling units, bases and manage economy but there are no build orders you just upgrade your current base to build more units.

A lot of people, myself included did not like this change. I am a big fan of 4X, strategy and RTS games, but this is more of a RPG, I would say the campaign itself is totally worth it if you buy it on a sale, then go ahead, and get ready to gear up your own space marine squad.

And the customization in the campaign is awesome, you want to give Terminator Armour to Assault Marines? They pick up the Thunder Hammers, give it to your marines and they turn into regular old Terminators, want some extra range for your assault gun-carrying Termies? Then give 'em the good cyclone missle launcher and let loose havoc.

The campaign really is the peak of this game and it lets you play from many different angles, but do keep in mind from an RTS point of view, Dawn of War I is the better multiplayer online game. But DoW also lets you play co-op in the campaign so if you just want to enjoy the Epic Space Marine bad assery with friends then totally pick this game up.

reviewText:
Dawn of War 2 forgoes its mix of micro and macro management gameplay from its previous series and focuses it all on small squad micro management. Here the player relies now more than ever on using terrain for squad, and structures as vantage points. This creates the pacing for multiplayer matches to become more about capture points rather than destruction of your enemy base. They have also removed creating tech tree structures, and streamlined the tech tree onto a single building.

You still have your unit upgrades per squad, and your race specific Heroes. But the cost for upgrades have increased, thus putting more weight onto fewer decisions. Replenishing squad units aren’t on the fly anymore, healing is only available at base. And, since there’s no mention of constructing a new base, you have only one location to heal, your starting point.

A match last about 30 minutes. However, the balancing feels a bit tilted. On a classic destruction game mode, if you control all the resources on the field within 10 minutes, you’ll find yourself spending the other 20 minutes trying to just break their base... unless if the AI happened to obtain unlimited resources, it appears they can heal almost indefinitely without any resource nodes. This is why they’ve probably added and defaulted the game mode to Capture Points, where you win by controlling the nodes.

If you want to compare this to other game genres, this would be similar to playing a DoTA/MoBA but with a single player controlling all the units on the field. While enjoyable to play, Dawn of War 2 is not my cup of tea.

reviewText:
I am just going to take a minute and write down a few thoughts I have had about this game as well as the additional games in this entire franchise. Because it is on a sale at this particular time I am jotting this down, I see from time to time a lot of people who wonder if they should get this game. The quick and easy answer is of course a most definite YES!, and I think for two very good reasons.

I will go ahead and put as the #1 reason is that, given how long this game has been out, the developers Relic Entertainment is in my opinion one the best video game development studios to have ever come along. They have done such an incredible job with the way they made this game. Everything from the production values to the voice over acting is just a perfect example of putting big budget resources to good use.

Another thing about this is, if you take a moment to look at the news and announcements pages for these games, Relic  is supporting this series and franchise to its fullest extent. There are lots of updates and general postings being made about these games on a constant basis to this day. Good communication with your player base goes a loooong way to helping people make good decisions about what games they should buy.

The #2 reason I could recommend getting this series and games, is that the level of polish and overall feel of the games themselves is very top notch. These games run extremely well across a huge variety of PC configurations, low end systems to the very latest PC's. Along with this is that these games play very good without huge game-breaking bugs ruining your playing experience, seems like Relic did a great job with making sure as many bugs were taken care of before they released this series a long time ago, in general I found that all of Relic's older games including CoH, The Homeworld series, etc. were done very well.

Some of the other things I enjoy about this series is that while I don't know a whole lot about the Warhammer Universe, I thought the story and characters are good enough to be interesting. Great campaign play, Good multiplayer action, and just altogether a solid, nicely done game series.

And lastly, I should go ahead and mention specifically that the DoW II games are just slightly different from the original W40K DoW series. The original DoW series had a classic C&C base-building, resource gathering model while the DoW II series switches over and gets rid that in favor of a squad based, heroes model.

Some people were surprised at the change, some liked it while others didn't, in my opinion it looked as if they wanted to go the other direction and that was fine. I would recommend in fact that anybody who wonders what the big difference is, is to maybe watch a youtube game review/let's play video that way you could see for yourself and decide that way because no one but you can decide if you would like that or not.

reviewText:
Dawn of War II is perhaps the best example of a sequel outside of StarCraft II in the RTS genre. While it tossed out Base Building for a more streamlined approach, it did so with flying colors combining Diablo style loot drops with an RPG leveling system and an extensive skill tree.

Pros: +Decent story with likeable characters
+Excellent loot, weapon, armor, and class variety
+Great graphics and animations that still hold up to todays standards for RTS games, especially for 2009
+TONS OF CONTENT! On top of a 20+ hour campaign that is highly replayable, you have Co-Op on top of that. (The online modes should be played exclusively on DoW II Retribution though as that has ALL the factions and the majority of the community.)
+Fantastic combat with great enemy variety, boss battles, special enemy types, and lots of guns, powers, and toys to play around with
+Huge open maps meant for exploration to find loot and other goodies as well as mop up any enemies to rack the experience points.
+Decent mission variety with story missions being the most focused with optional Assassination and Defense missions to spice it up
+The voice acting is SUPERB with some of the best game actors in the biz working it, including Steve Blum, aka Spike from Cowboy Beebop in this game as a grizzled Sniper expert
+ITS WARHAMMER 40K! If you love the franchise like I do you will be splooging at all the detail, lore, and awesome stuff that helps build upon the license and makes you giddy just to feel like youre in the universe of W40K

Con: -Graphics are great overall, but there is some serious texture quality that is left to be desired, like the ground for instance
-While the maps are expansive and fun to explore they repeat them CONSTANTLY in the game. It gets repeitive doing the same maps over and over, but it's the quality of the gameplay and the map design that save this unfortunate problem
-Cant respec skill tree :(
-Still suffers from bugs. Nothing major, but there are occasional animation bugs where units may get stuck or cant move, and enemies who get killed may fly in circles around the map. It's actually kind of funny when you see that one though
-Along with repeating maps the missions themselves feel very repetitive after a while. It's the differing enemy types and awesome loot drops that encourage you to play these and save this unforunate repetition
-While the writing is passable by W40K fans, most people will see it as stock and cliche. It really is the setting and license that hold it up. The characters are memorable and likeable enough, but fairly one dimensional in personality and you really need to listen to a LOT of their dialog to feel invested

OVERALL: Fantastic
I mean no exageration when I award this a 9.5/10 as a W40K fan. As an RTS/RPG fan, I award it an 8.5 for those not familiar with W40K. An excellent game none the less and one of my favorite games of all time and my favorite RTS alongside StarCraft II. An easy buy.

reviewText:
Heresy!

What do you get when you take a different, albeit risky, spin on a popular franchise? You get Dawn of War II, a squad/tactics-based strategy game set in the Warhammer 40,000 universe which is also the first proper sequel in the Dawn of War series.

What is striking in Dawn of War II is how Relic decided to throw away all of the base-building and army management mechanics - staples of the strategy genre - and focus on squad/tactics-based mechanics instead where you can control of up to four (out of six) unique squads and capture points throughout various missions in the campaign. In other words, it is something like taking exclusive control of heroes in Warcraft 3. On top of that, light RPG mechanics were seamlessly implemented to give a bit more depth to the gameplay by allowing the player to level up their squads, assigning attribute points, unlocking new abilities, collecting dropped loot and customizing war-gears to their will; essentially a character progression system. These RPG mechanics, while basic, do provide some diversity in tactics when preparing for a mission.

With no prior knowledge of Warhammer 40,000’s lore, aside from these Space Marines worshipping this Emperor of theirs and barbarically killing Tyranids (and other races), as if they are BJ Blazkowicz on steroids, Dawn of War II is actually capable of providing an interesting and somewhat immersive story, albeit nothing new to this genre though, with a fairly strong narrative even to someone who knows absolutely nothing about the Warhammer universe, like myself. About an hour or so in the campaign, you will quickly familiarise yourself with the lore in no time. However, this time around you are allowed to play whichever mission your heart desires in the campaign, with each pick having a certain consequence depending on its objectives. If you want to take a break from the main story-missions, distress calls act as secondary missions for you to complete within a limited time, despite most of them getting generic after a time. At least this creates a layer of non-linearity in the campaign, even if it is all just an illusion. And once again, unquestionable high production values all around coming from someone like Relic, especially in its visuals and voice acting. Where do they find these voice actors?

Relic has been known for making good campaigns in their games, even memorable ones as seen in Company of Heroes, but ultimately everyone plays these games for the multiplayer. And there is no denying that Relic did well here too, again. With co-op added, it is possible to play the campaign with a friend and/or battle against each other in either the Victory Point Control or Annihilation modes. But the real meat of the multiplayer is in the Last Stand mode where you have to survive waves of AI controlled units. It is simply addicting and so much fun to play in this mode, especially with a group of friends. No wonder most current servers just run the Last Stand mode, because it is that popular.

Sadly where Dawn of War II falls short is in its small and quite uninspiring map designs, repetitiveness in some of its mission objectives and levels, underwhelming boss-fights, squads’ poor path-finding and the lack of other playable races in the campaign (see the expansions packs); having different perspectives from different factions is always a bonus in a story. Also, once you clear out the campaign, there is little reason for coming back to it straightaway since the story, while pretty good, is not worth another playthrough for quite some time; unless you want to play on a higher difficulty, collect all of the achievements or maybe delve into co-op with a friend.

And frankly, while the gameplay is probably not as deep (as you may wanted it to be), it can still deliver plenty of hours of fun regardless. Come to think of it, the reason why it is fun is because it is simplified, stripped down from its original roots. No more headaches from micromanaging all your troops across big maps. In actual fact, it is almost like playing a MOBA game, minus some aspects and without that overwhelming depth in gameplay. Moreover, due to the small size of most maps, a mission can take can up to around 15 minutes to complete, with multiplayer matches lasting potentially longer depending on skills. This eliminates the possibility of long-winded plays and getting tired by them, although this is fairly subjective.

In conclusion, Dawn of War II is a good example where a developer took the risk to try something dynamically new on a popular and acclaimed franchise to at least satisfactory results. Whether this might have caused them to lose some hardcore fans whilst also gaining new ones, I personally do not care. It is a solid squad/tactics-based strategy game nonetheless, backed up by a story faithful to the Warhammer universe, a well-written narrative, high production values (as we are accustomed from Relic) and a strong multiplayer component thanks to its co-op and Last Stand mode, but definitely not without glaring flaws. Overall nothing mind-blowing, but it is tons of fun. If you are looking for a straightforward traditional RTS, either pick the original Dawn of War or try any other RTS out there instead, if you are desperately missing the good-old base-building and army management mechanics. Otherwise, this is a solid recommendation regardless if you know anything about Warhammer in general.

And who needs to wear a helmet in combat when you have oversized body armours which weight a tonne and have jump packs? Crazy, I know. And very impractical.

reviewText:
The game that first took me down the rabbit hole that is WARHAMMER 40000, this is one terrific experience.
Quick version: if you like WARHAMMER 40k, buy it. If you like RTS games, buy it.

Long version: Dawn of War II is a tight-playing squad-based RTS that feels just right for my brain. The campaign is a ton of fun, with lots of loot to collect and abilities to unlock. You’ll want to tackle multiple playthroughs to try out different character builds. Deliciously campy and fun voice acting abounds. The multiplayer is terrific as well, plus the recent removal of the much hated Games For Windows Live makes it all the sweeter.

Get the whole franchise package when it goes on cheap. You’ll get a solid 30 hours at least out of DOW II and its two excellent expansions and never look back.

PURGE THE XENOS

reviewText:
Hey you! Yes you! Would you like to command a squad in an epic battle against countless enemies across a subsector? Well in Warhammer 40,000 Dawn of War 2 you can do just that! in this game you play as a force commander of the Blood Ravens Space Marines and you lead a small team of elite soldiers in defence of the Blood Ravens recruiting worlds (aka homeworlds) in the Aurealia sub-system.

Now gameplay wise, this game is a great example of squad based tactics done in a reasonable fashion due to the hordes of enemies you have to face down with just a hand full of men. The only problem i have with the gameplay is that it does away with the base building of the previous Dawn of War but if you look at this game as if it were a plot sequal and not a gameplay sequal then the game is actually rather good.

I fully reccomend this game to anyone who likes a nice good fast-paced RTS that requires you to think on your feet and look at everything with a tactical eye.

reviewText:
After having a blast with the original Dawn of War (review link) I decided to pick up the sequel, and I'm glad that I did.
The Blood Ravens are back to dispense Space Marine justice once again, and this time it's personal!

I don't mean that they have actual personal investments in the story or anything though, this is Warhammer after all.
The main difference this time around is that you only control a small number of hero squads (usually 4) in each level, so the focus is far more on squad management and tactics than the previous game. The previous game had some of that too, but definitely a lot of economy and base building too. None of that here though, this is purely a combat game.

Your heroes level up as they purge the xenos (that's Space Marine for killing just about everything) and each level up grants them a passive stat boost, 2 skill points and access to better gear (which drops randomly from enemies you kill, almost like an ARPG, but fortunately not quite as frequently).
These skill points (and your choice of weapon type and accessories) are your primary means of customization, and you can spend them on 4 attributes. Health, Ranged, Melee and Energy. The first 3 are self-explanatory, and Energy just gives you more mana" to use your abilities in battle. What elevates this system to something far more strategic though
date: is that specific levels in an attribute can give very specific effects. For example
recommended: putting 3 points in Energy could unlock an additional accessory slot or allow your units to equip plasma rifles.\nThere aren't enough skill points to get everything though
hoursPlayed: as the maximum level is 20 (for your units anyway
voteText: I've seen enemy AI with level 27 units... I hate it when games do that). This means that you'll have to decide how to develop your units quite early on
helpfulPercent: and with no way to respec them and a total of 6 (steady) party members unlocked as the game progresses it is possible that you screw up your build and will have a harder time.\n\nIn general the game is pretty fair though
votesHelpful: and as long as you don't split up your squad or rush into enemy fire unprepared (which will 'suppress' your squad
votesTotal: drastically lowering its movement speed) you should be okay. There is a range of difficulty settings too
votesFunny: though this can't be changed once you start your campaign.\nI personally went through the game on the lowest difficulty setting
commentsCount: Recruit
column16: and felt sufficiently challenged (lost 2 optional missions
column17: which I was then able to redo at a later time).\n\nThe story is the standard 40k fare. Sub-sector Aurelia is important to every 40k race
column18: and as the Imperium presence is overrun with Orks the Blood Ravens are called in. This quickly escalates into a conflict against the insidious Eldar and relentless Tyranid as well.\n\nIn general I had a great time with this game
column19: and I'd definitely recommend it.\nYou're still only able to play as the Space Marines
column20: and they're still stupidly serious about everything
column21: but as a power fantasy they definitely deliver."

reviewText: Took me awhile to decide how to review this one. If you expect it to be like Dawn of War I and its many expansions, you will be disappointed. If you expect it to be like Starcraft or other iconic RTS titles, you also will be disappointed. If you go into it expecting it to be entirely new and different you will have a great time. I personally haven’t played another RTS with a similar system. In the campaign mode, base building is nonexistent. You can deploy four squads and the gameplay relies heavily on how you position them and use cover. The squad customization system between maps is immense. I have a total of six squads and between all the different gear combos you can really custom tailor your playstyle. I haven’t yet played the base building multiplayer; I am still getting use to this combat system. Based solely on the campaign mode, I am confident giving this game a positive rating because it is simply super fun and has a great dynamic story. If you like Warhammer 40k I don’t think you can go wrong here. Also if you are tired of the same old rehashed RTS gameplay, this one is for you. Also, yes the Tyranids are super BA.

reviewText: For those expecting a sequel to Dawn of War be prepared to be slightly disappointed because the threads of similarity are very thin. Yes it’s based in the 40K universe, Space Marines battling Orks etc. But that is it, Dawn of War 2 is a game in its own right, you will not be amassing squads of soldiers capturing strategic locations to earn more points so you can build more units faster. In fact the main emphasis will be around a small group of rock hard units which you will take (or not) on missions amass experience and hopefully pick up wargear. Dawn of War was a RTS pure and simple, Dawn of War 2 is a cross between RTS and RPG. I enjoyed playing the game in its own right and would highly recommend it for both RTS, RPG and 40K fans.

reviewText: Took me awhile to decide how to review this one. If you expect it to be like Dawn of War I and its many expansions, you will be disappointed. If you expect it to be like Starcraft or other iconic RTS titles, you also will be disappointed. If you go into it expecting it to be entirely new and different you will have a great time. I personally haven’t played another RTS with a similar system. In the campaign mode, base building is nonexistent. You can deploy four squads and the gameplay relies heavily on how you position them and use cover. The squad customization system between maps is immense. I have a total of six squads and between all the different gear combos you can really custom tailor your playstyle. I haven’t yet played the base building multiplayer; I am still getting use to this combat system. Based solely on the campaign mode, I am confident giving this game a positive rating because it is simply super fun and has a great dynamic story. If you like Warhammer 40k I don’t think you can go wrong here. Also if you are tired of the same old rehashed RTS gameplay, this one is for you. Also, yes the Tyranids are super BA.

reviewText: This game is a great combination of graphics, story, and stratagy into one game. The graphics when either zoomed in or out are amazing from the background and buildings to the units themshelves it is clear and prestine and not pixally at all. The fact you can see all the armour and weapon details on your squads makes me feel it is not just about stats. The story is great in how it blends all these different Warhammer races into one amazing story and the converstaions between your squad sergents allows you to get to know them and there personalities. Lastly is the stratagy without the ability to build buildings to get endless units you have to think more carefully about which squads to take on a mission by reading the bonus information on each mission.  Some missions present a hard challange at times which can be both frustrating and enjoyable at the same time. At one moment you could be crusing along plowing down units easily next you could be bogged down reviving your units or redoing a mission for the fourth time in a row. So beside haveing to think more on which squads to take and how hard some missions can be to me this is a good all round game.\n\n

reviewText: I intially thought that this game was just going to be a way for 40k to advertise their movie or their board games with a few ♥♥♥♥♥♥ graphics and alot of explosions. My friends, I was sadly mistaken. The amount of depth and effort put into this game is very apparent. The battlefield tactics are wonderfully designed and very balanced. The graphics and background to the worlds you explore are extremely well thought out and put together. Unlike most games, who either prioritize story telling or gameplay mechanic elements, the designers did an amazing job making both engaging and worthwhile. While you won't find hours upon hours of different gameplay in it's PvP multiplayer, it does come with a very interesting and well thought out PvE multiplayer that I personally enjoy playing with friends. Brings the glory of the Warhammer universe, the fun interactive style of the RTS genre, and the immersive graphics of the next gen engines together beautifully. Had fun, would love to see more content created for this game.   9/10

reviewText:
As a lover of strategy games, I have to say this game is quite a blast (and refreshing for those who are used to base-building strategy games).

This was my first time playing it so I think I will bother to describe my experience from the very beggining.

First, the campaign, the characters have base personalities and they don't strave from them, instead they develop while you advance in the game, side missions are not just side missions, since characters themselves give it some thought and weight after you complete it.

The gameplay is fun, quick and easy to catch up with, it's nothing complicated, you can take your time to complete missions, capture important buildings and wipe everyone out, or take the easy way out and blast your guns through hordes of enemies right to the objective. The game rewards you for not having your teammates defeated in the whole mission (they can be revived), the amount of enemies downed and the time you took to complete said mission.

The upgrade system is fairly understandable, it could be your usual MMO if it wasn't because even though stats don't increase much, they still matter in battle, and special abilities unlocked while you level up help turn the tides on battles that you wouldn't even dream of accomplishing without said abilities.


The Last Stand? Well, now that's a fun thing, I haven't catched the hang of it (seriously, first 3 times playing it and I got squashed in them all, except for one with a level 20 guy), but I'm getting there. The gamemode itself is interesting albeit challenging, and it can be fun if you have people who can play correctly, and are up to flaws. It just boils down to tolerance, but, that gamemode, no questions asked, is extremely fun.

I haven't tried multiplayer, but I have high expectations.

I would *absolutely* buy this game if I had the money, it's amazing.

reviewText: I loved this game so damned much, the expansions were all great, and the modes were great. This is a tactical game, not really an RTS. Last stand is great but does get a bit old after a while. Played the living crap out of every mode and bought every expansion and can't reccomend it highly enough.

reviewText:
Fans of the Warhammer universe rejoice! Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War II is the sequel to Dawn of War where the epic tale of the Blood Ravens continues.

Control & Gameplay:
Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War ll renews the Dawn of War genre by adding some new core elements. The well known base building and creation of armies have been replaced by tight squad control, where the micromanagement of these squads will lead to a successful mission. You control each squad's loadout, specialization, abilities and generally everything about them. You will also need to take heed of the terrain, where to take cover, where to move and so on. This might seem as a giant leap away from the first Dawn of War series, and it certainly is. It takes some time to become accustomed with the new game mechanics, but once you get settled, the game is quite enjoyable. In campaign mode, each mission will allow you to choose 4 specialized squads who gain XP and items by completing each mission. There is a fixed number of squads to choose from. In multiplayer, the goal is to capture points and hold them, while building additional squads to supplement your commander in battle. The only building available on the field of battle is the headquarters, from which you can spawn more troops.

The controls are accurate and function without any trouble. In multiplayer, however, if a player is experiencing lag issues, it will affect the entire match, thus rendering control of your units more difficult or even impossible, if someone has a high latency. However, this issue is not prevalent, at least not from my experience.

Fun Factor:
Apart from the new style of gameplay, which can be a huge turn off for some players, Dawn of War ll is as original in its story as the previous games. The story remains rich and plays a significant part in the game, as you uncover dark secrets regarding the unknown past of the Blood Ravens.
Currently, the game is being converted to Steamworks from Games for Windows Live. Therefore, if anyone chooses to buy the game now, beware that large segments of multiplayer is currently unavailable for use.

Graphics & Audio
The visual aspect of the game is a continuation from the previous style: still dark and gritty, but with added details.
The soundtrack is heavy and it enhances the coarse and gritty quality of the game. For the most part, it supplements the game subliminally. After a while, I did not even notice it due to the constant shooting and blowing up of mines, detonation charges and xeno matter flying around.

Replayability:
I have spent 100+ hours on this game already, so I would argue that the replayability is indeed high. Even more so with the two expansions: Chaos Rising and Retribution.
In the original Dawn of War 2, there is a campaign and multiplayer mode. Additionally, the campaign can be played both singleplayer and multiplayer through COOP, which I would highly recommend.
Furthermore, another mode was introduced, namely The Last Stand". Here
date:
a group of 3 commandos are pitted against 20 waves of unrelenting xenos. Definitely worth hours of fun and frustration.

Conclusion:
Despite the fact that Dawn of War ll has moved away from the original Dawn of War games in terms of mechanics
recommended: the game still offers exciting gameplay
hoursPlayed: a well-structed narrative and solid campaign. Where the older games focused on base building and overwhelming your opponent
voteText: the new games focus on managing a handful of specialist squads. Terrain

votesTotal: this is the only huge minus about the game
votesFunny: for the time being. This will soon change

reviewText: With a improved engine and a redesign game, Dawn of War 2 take places in a slighly smaller scale from the orginal. Good gear customization and tactics really do come into play in this game vs the original where you could just throw the book at them. Boss fights can get hairy and somtimes are stupidly difficult but with proper planning and tactics are winnable.  All and all i would say that i did enjoy this game i just wish they had included a bit more into it."

reviewText:
I am a huge fan of the Warhammer 40,000 universe. My first exposure to this world was the original Dawn of War franchise, and I loved how they tweaked the traditional RTS style with a new squad based style.

With Dawn of War 2 they did it again; the game wasn't going to adhere to standardised conventions. While never fully either an RTS or RPG, it contained the best of these elements. Think party based RPG with loot drops!

The game allows you to appreaciate the Space Marine as it should be - a small squad of super human soldiers cutting its way through a multitude of enemies to achieve its objective. No hunkering behind defenses, no building a bigger army than necessary. You are dropped in the centre of the action and you have to literally carve your way through with bolter and chainsword.

The story is relatively straight forward, but you will be constantly drawn back to the high paced visceral action and adrenaline rushing music. Nothing can relieve stress as effectively as dropping your assault marines on top of a cluster of enemies and making them go splash.

First one works as a classic RTS, with matches/single player campaigns where you build structures, gather resources conquering nodes and recruit/upgrade troops to attack your enemies's base, in order to win.

Second one, this one and the Retribution, have a bit different RTS strategy in the singleplayer mode: you control squads of marines with different skills and utility, and accomplish some missions in the area where you drop in, mostly of the time requires you to kill every alien being, even if you are outnumbered, all of this with an exp system that upgrades the squad captains and item drops that improve their stats. The Retribution is the same thing, but with many more campaigns where you can play any race/faction existing in the DoW universe.
Both of these games have also a co-op mode that is called The Last Stand, where you choose a unit from any race (in DoW II you need to buy the Chaos Expansion to play one race, and a DLC to play another unit in the DoW II: Retribution), team up with other 2 players and survive as many possible waves you can, using many skills to either control areas, destroy enemies, support allies, etc.

And the last one, Space Marine"
date: is a fighting game in third person where you'll take part as a space marine in a war against the Orks and Eretics (obviously
recommended: you'll be outnumbered here too)\n\nAs i said
hoursPlayed: every game of the serie is great
voteText: but for a new RTS style i suggest you trying this out
helpfulPercent: and then move on the other games to get the emperor's blessing
votesHelpful: like i did.\nFOR THY EMPEROR"

reviewText: I was absolutely blown away by this game. I never expected it to live up to the first. But I have never been to delightfully wrong. If you are looking for a copy past of the first title this isn't it. It's a completely new experience and all for the best. It's less RTS and more action RPG. You take control over a small kill team of Blood Raven Marines that as you progress can mix and match to adapt to various missions. The story was as solid as could be and the game play was fluid and beautiful. I spent countless hours on this one years back. And didn't hesitate to buy it again on Steam. An absolute must for ANY 40K fan new and old and worth a test drive for players who have no idea what 40K is all about.

reviewText:
Relic Entertainment really outdid their previous best work when they came to making Dawn of War 2 and it's two expansion packs, Chaos Rising and Retribution. Simply put, they are by far the best video game adaptation of the Warhammer 40,000 universe to date.

In diverging from the now stale traditional RTS game model, and integrating some elements from the RPG genre, Relic have created a masterpiece of strategy gaming. Fast paced but refined, it is a far better game than it's launch year competitor, Starcraft 2, simply down to the fact the design of its gameplay is over a decade more advanced in terms of evolution and innovation. By improving on the the original Dawn of War formula by blending its best elements and mechanics with those from Company of Heroes, Dawn of War 2 delivers an experience unlike any other on offer.

With DoW2, Relic once again demonstrate their repect for Games Workshops most popular setting, creating a 40K game with the love and care of the most dedicated tabletop fan. The story is the typical cheesy sci-fi goodness we've come to expect of 40K. The visuals are still incredible, and stand up very well compared with even new releases. Also, like always with Relic, the sound is flawless, drawing you completely into the setting and story with ease.

By design, DoW2 is more like three games rolled into one. The Campaign mode (which can also be played co-operatively), a PvP Multiplayer mode and a Co-op Multiplayer mode known as The Last Stand". The three components are similar in feel
date: but differ slightly in terms of gameplay
recommended: offering a unique experience for each game mode. All three modes are extremely fun in their own right
hoursPlayed: and combined have provided me with months worth of entertainment.\n\nTo sum up
voteText: Dawn of War 2 (plus expansions) are some of the very best strategy games ever made
helpfulPercent: and if they even slightly peak your curiosity
votesHelpful: you should buy them. Now. You won't regret it.\n\nFOR THE EMPEROR!"

reviewText:
This is one of the best 40k games to ever come out. However, its an awful strategy game. Get this because you love 40k, not because you love RTS games.

Graphics:  Incredible for the time. They have aged well too.
Audio: The voice acting in this game is great. Easily some of the best voice acting I've ever heard. Each character's voice fits well to their role and is acted well. The only problem, which is hardly a problem, is too much steve blum.
Gameplay: This game downsizes from the last dawn of war and is more of a squad based RPG than a RTS. There is a cover system which is better than the cover that was in the first dawn of war in that it actually feels like the cover is helping rather than making you squat in a crater. Unforutantely, due to the squad based nature of the game, the multiplayer is lacking at best. Games are long, combat is rare, stratgy is lacking, and it really just feels like someone took company of heroes, shrank it a bit, and gave it 40k units.
Story: The story is well written. It makes the game feel like a desperate gambit for surivival against odds only a spacemarine could surmount. The only problem is reused maps.
Overall: 8/10. Play it cause you want to lead a badass squad of blood ravens and listen to steve blum tell steve blum that steve blum is a really dangerous  steve blum.

reviewText:
Alright, where do I start? First of all, I have no ties to the Warhammer 40K universe. I've never read the books, I don't have any of the figurines, and I've never played any of the other games. The only prior knowledge I had about the lore was space orcs, with guns. I was never interested in this game. My brother gave me a 75% off coupon and I bought it, installed it, and played it. I can safely say it is  one of my favorite game of all time.

An outline of the game. Dawn of War II is a Real Time Strategy based in the Warhammer 40K. It is a cover based game where you always have 4 squads on the field (you get the ability to change out squads for other squads with different abilities). This game also has a little bit of an RPG element thrown into it. You can customize the armor, weapons, and accessories, as well as leveling up your squad with XP points.

The game is centered in the subsector of Aurelia, where there are three planets that you orbit between. There are missions on the three planets. The missions usually consist of go here kill this or destroy this. The missions do kind of get a little bit repetitive but as to where it's a problem *cough PAYDAY2 cough*.

There is also a multiplayer feature. You can play cooperatively or competitively. In co-op you can either do the campaign, where two people control two squads. The other game mode is skirmish, where you can either fight with or against your friends, as different races.

Now on to the pros and cons of the game:

Pros:
Simple but nice mechanics
RPG elements
Nice story for an RTS
Slicing through low level enemy’s with a high level plasma canon.

Cons:
Repetitive missions
Repetitive missions
Two of my squads got stuck on an invisible wall once

Despite its faults, few faults that is, Dawn of War is an excellent game. I would recommend this game to newbies of 40K, like me, and veterans.
9/10

reviewText:
Relic Entertainment made some incredible RTS games with the Warhammer 40,000 license. In an era after the release of Warcraft III, many were wondering what else was left to do with the genre. It seemed honed to perfection by Blizzard's creation and no follow-up to Starcraft was even announced.

While the initial release was mainly an introduction to the universe for more casual fans, the expansions molded the overall experience into a galaxy spanning, epic tale of betrayal, revenge, violence and Orcs. It definitely captured a few years of my life, to be sure.

While the final expansion to the first game (Soulstorm) was a bit of a letdown, Relic's then brand new Company of Heroes showed a different side of an RTS. It was more action oriented, with less emphasis on tactical planning and more on reactionary combat. It felt like an actual war, instead of how RTS games had played out in the past.

With Dawn of War II, Relic has adapted a similar style to the campaign that they used in Company of Heroes. You no longer focus on building a base, queueing up units and acquiring upgrades. The moment to moment gameplay is about utilizing the abilities of your squad and conquering your foes with minimal damage.

It makes for situations that feel overwhelming and create a real sense of accomplishment over meager skirmishes. Ramping up the difficulty leads to even crazier encounters, but the game never feels like it's totally out of your control. The RPG-lite system used to level up your units is one way to mitigate any potential difficulty.

Another comes from the loadouts you can equip your commander with. Things like grenades, shields, medkits, artillery strikes and other weapons give you a lot of control over how you tackle each level. That the campaign missions never start feeling boring is also a plus, since it's fun to mix and match tactics while constantly having to adapt to new problems.

The only real downside is that the story is particularly drab. I know the names of my units since they love to talk about themselves, but I couldn't tell you the overarching threat or what is even really going on. The ending is pretty sweet (even with the fake out), but there isn't a real cathartic payoff for the amount of effort you put in.

I'd love to comment about the multiplayer (since this game is now free of Games for Windows Live), but I guess everyone has moved on to the second expansion, Retribution. I did find a few matches and Last Stand mode, in particular, is great, but there just isn't that big of a community on the original non-Steam games.

That aside, the netplay does function and is nearly lag-free, so playing co-op with a friend is a completely viable option. That the prospect doesn't fill me with dread also shows how engaging the gameplay in Dawn of War II really is.

8.5/10

There were no technical issues or bugs that I encountered.\n\nIt's frustrating that the continuation of the Dawn of War series has been complicated by changing ownership & THQ's fate.  I'll believe there's a third installment in the works only when I can click the preorder button on Steam's store page!  WH40K:DoW2 is showing its age visually but is otherwise an admirably well crafted game that holds up to modern standards well enough; I highly recommend it for the excellent science fiction and solid RTS strategy - and obviously it's a must play for any Warhammer fan."

reviewText:
Alright, where do I start? First of all, I have no ties to the Warhammer 40K universe. I've never read the books, I don't have any of the figurines, and I've never played any of the other games. The only prior knowledge I had about the lore was space orcs, with guns. I was never interested in this game. My brother gave me a 75% off coupon and I bought it, installed it, and played it. I can safely say it is  one of my favorite game of all time.

An outline of the game. Dawn of War II is a Real Time Strategy based in the Warhammer 40K. It is a cover based game where you always have 4 squads on the field (you get the ability to change out squads for other squads with different abilities). This game also has a little bit of an RPG element thrown into it. You can customize the armor, weapons, and accessories, as well as leveling up your squad with XP points.

The game is centered in the subsector of Aurelia, where there are three planets that you orbit between. There are missions on the three planets. The missions usually consist of go here kill this or destroy this. The missions do kind of get a little bit repetitive but as to where it's a problem *cough PAYDAY2 cough*.

There is also a multiplayer feature. You can play cooperatively or competitively. In co-op you can either do the campaign, where two people control two squads. The other game mode is skirmish, where you can either fight with or against your friends, as different races.

Now on to the pros and cons of the game:

Pros:
Simple but nice mechanics
RPG elements
Nice story for an RTS
Slicing through low level enemy’s with a high level plasma canon.

Cons:
Repetitive missions
Repetitive missions
Two of my squads got stuck on an invisible wall once

Despite its faults, few faults that is, Dawn of War is an excellent game. I would recommend this game to newbies of 40K, like me, and veterans.
9/10

reviewText: I was absolutely blown away by this game. I never expected it to live up to the first. But I have never been to delightfully wrong. If you are looking for a copy past of the first title this isn't it. It's a completely new experience and all for the best. It's less RTS and more action RPG. You take control over a small kill team of Blood Raven Marines that as you progress can mix and match to adapt to various missions. The story was as solid as could be and the game play was fluid and beautiful. I spent countless hours on this one years back. And didn't hesitate to buy it again on Steam. An absolute must for ANY 40K fan new and old and worth a test drive for players who have no idea what 40K is all about.

reviewText:
LONG REVIEW, WITH TL,DR AT THE END.
I did not play the previous Warhammer 40k RTS games before Dawn of War II, yet I'm aware how different they are and I understand why some may not like Dawn of War II as the next evolution of the Dawn of War series. It's true, it is completely different, through that's no reason for hate or prejudgement. Dawn of War II on it's own is a fantastic game, I risk to say maybe ageless to be picked up again years after for it's campign, and if you don't expect an FPS game to be TPS, you'll realize if everything else other than the perspective is marvelously done, you have a great game.

The same applies to Dawn of War II. It has left behind base building completely, the entire campign is leading a relatively small elite force, in a gameplay setting that is equal to classic RTS games, plus you have the cover system from Company of Heroes, and a lot RPG elements. This, as is, works freaking great. You expect it be a base building resource gathering army building game, well it's not, and that's no reason to hate it (reacting to the negative reviews).

The gameplay itself is fluid, smart. Tactics, strategies, adapting to new situations and changing (destroyable) enviroment
is vital to success, and can be greatly different from playthrough to playthrough, from player to player, depending on the playstyle, RPG build (skill tree and equipment that drasticly change your squad) you choose.

The graphics are fantastic up to this day, even if the game can be considered somewhat aged" in 2016

reviewText:
I don't really like RTS games because my base building somehow never worked. Of course, this was a decade ago and my coordination has gotten better. The primary reasons, though, that I tried Dawn of War 2 out was because there was no base building. This made the game very tactical and my units more valuable. I couldn't just produce more meat for the grinder without risking my important units.

Oh and the story is pretty okay. Characters tend to be macho, but since I was using these characters over and over during battle, I've gotten attached to some. Even though your character, the Force Commander, never speaks, you feel like your doing something because the units ALWAYS compliment your leadership rather than their badass abilities.

It's also a Wahmmer 40k game. THere's a lot of lore and what not, which makes me wonder why there hasn't been an RPG made yet.

So... droning on....... It's a good game? 9/10.

reviewText: Well, in a recent sale I bought the master collection (not grand master) of Dawn of war 2 and my only previous experience with this series is soulstorm on disk. If you want to just play skirmish with friends, I can't compare it to any other dawn of war 1 games, but soulstorm is much better than this. If you want a campaign that is quite frankly stupid (although still fun), and the last stand game mode, where you just play an HQ, like a sh*t moba, with 2 allies against hordes of enemies, then get this. I have played one skirmish with friends as of writing this. There are no builder units, and a lot of the squads I built started with max capacity. There were only 5 different armies to choose from, although you could change the colour scheme with no other effects I can find, although it was quite fun. Not having any of the other DLC, I can't really judge this game in its entirity, but I can't see it improving it to be better than soulstorm in skirmish (do buy the steam version, as the disk version's online multiplayer isn't nice to use). If you read the entirity of this, I hope you can appreciate how much damage sleep deprivation causes.
