reviewText:
TLDR – Dawn of War 2 is real time strategy game that borrows squad type combat from Company of Heroes (same game developer). Despite the RPG elements and seemingly overwhelming odds in each level, the game really isn’t that difficult if you take your time, so don’t let that turn you off. If you like epic sci-fi stories and real time strategy, you should enjoy DOW 2.

In this game, you play a “force commander” in the Blood Ravens, a chapter of the badass Imperial Space Marines. This isn’t just a story line thing, your commander unit is deployed in every level and you run him around shooting and chopping bad guys like a hero unit in Warcraft 3. If you’ve played Warhammer games before you should recognize most of your enemies this time around. The Orks are brutish thugs (as you would expect from orcs) and the Eldar are high tech psychic aliens (kind of like Protoss in Starcraft). The Space Marines as usual have made it their mission to wipe out all aliens in the galaxy, meaning you fight everyone everywhere. This time around you face a new threat, the Tyranid Hive Swarm (much like the Zerg in Starcraft) which is invading your sector of space, killing humans, Orks, and Eldar alike.

First of all, if you’re used to real time strategy games like Starcraft, Warcraft, or Command & Conquer, there are a few key differences you should know right off the bat:
•	This game is more “tactical” than strategy, meaning you do not build anything (buildings/units). You start each mission with all the troops you’re going to get (except missions where they introduce your new squads).
•	You can only deploy 4 squads per mission (total of 6 available), and they are all “heroes” meaning they level up and can be equipped with weapons/armor/accessories. They also all have special abilities and “mana” to cast spells. You’re going to be doing a bunch of micromanagement throughout the game.
•	All of your units have both melee and ranged attacks, and you can toggle which one to use. This isn’t a feature in many real time strategy games and you can exploit it in some cases (suppress the enemy with heavy ranged attacks and then charge in with melee to wipe them out).
•	Between missions, you often get to choose where you will deploy next. Even the story missions can sometimes be played in your choice of order. This became a problem for me because the order I played the missions unlocked a certain unit almost at the end of the game, and he turned out to be my favorite.
•	Note that you will be playing on the same 12 or so maps throughout the campaign, but starting at different points on the map. This is because all of your battles are fought in the same sub sector of space, and you’re competing with the aliens to hold ground. Also keep in mind that most maps have special buildings that you can capture, providing bonuses to your overall war effort. Start early and capture as many as you can because holding these buildings offers special “defense missions” where you try to survive waves of alien attacks (more missions means more exp and item drops).
•	Another thing to note is that you can’t save the game manually during missions, it autosaves between missions. If you quit a mission, you get a loss on your record.

Pros:
+Excellent storytelling and a variety of aliens to pound on. If you’re a fan of Warhammer, don’t miss out.
+Simplified gameplay, just your 4 squads vs large hordes of enemies and occasional bosses. Don’t just charge in or you’ll be wiped out.
+The game has co-op campaign gameplay available. You and your friend can play through the single player campaign, each controlling 2 squads (instead of you controlling all 4). This can be helpful if you’re bad at micromanagement, like me.

Cons:
-Like the Company of Heroes games, there seems to be a lot of luck involved in the gameplay, specifically in gun accuracy. Normally you wouldn’t expect real time strategy games to have units missing their shots so much. It’s not really a bad thing, but it can take some getting used to. Also, the ability to charge in with melee units or throw grenades really negates the “cover” system.
-A minor gripe, but it seems like a bunch of the game’s Steam achievements are for playing ranked multiplayer matches and for the Chaos Rising DLC.

Overall, the game is fun and will last you quite a while (took about 14 hours to beat). Each individual mission is short (you get bonus exp for finishing faster), but the single player campaign is lengthy and you have many variables to choose from when it comes to skilling and equipping your squads. You can’t just mass produce units and crush the enemy like other real time strategy games, you actually have to guide them with some semblance of skill.  Also, if you play the multiplayer, be warned that gameplay is drastically different from the single player campaign. You have to build units and tech up like in standard real time strategy games.

reviewText:
This game was one of my favourites. And it's still a great one to have in mind. Probably the best thing is the campaign mode, as well as the coop mode. Mostly, thanks to Games for Windows' horrible matchmaking system.

This game's graphics are quite beautiful, for its time. And very few games of that time had dynamic environments, in which you can virtually destroy everything. That was amazing, but developers did not only create a modifiable, pretty environment, but they as well made a great job creating a game with so many strategical possibilities, even before the mission has started. You can choose which squads deploy, with which skills do they do it, which loadout are they going to have... And then during game, the cover system is absolutely delightful to use. There is absolutely no way you can play and win this just based on luck. You totally need to think carefully every movemente from the Normal difficulty campaign, let alone harder ones.

But then, when you have gone tired of playing this game alone (which, believe me, will take a long time), you are going to want to play the multiplayer one. And that's not going to be so pleasant. When this game wasn't so old, it was hard to find a 3v3 multiplayer game. Nowadays it's impossible. The only mode that works more or less as it should is the coop one, and, even though it's fine, long queues and GOW matchmaking system will probably make you stop playing multiplayer soon. Along with some toxic players, as always.

In spite of all that, this game is one of the best RTS ones you are ever going to find. It gets you plotting plans from the first 3 minutes, guaranteed.

reviewText:
Warhammer 40K Dawn of War 2 is the first pure example of THQ's new take on the real time strategy genre. The resource gathering is all but gone and there are no structures to build, production or defensive. Instead you get to control small squads of soldiers with a variety of abilities in a micro battle against either the single-player hordes or an equally micro intensive multi-player opponent.

Dawn of War 2 stands a bit a part from other RTS's by having the single-player campaign and the multi-player battles play rather differently. In single-player you control individual soldiers, heroes if you will, through various maps filled with entrenched enemies and a boss at the end in a very RPG-like fashion. Your heroes gain experience, unlock new abilities and collect wargear to improve themselves along the way.

The story is great and captures the WH40K feel quite nicely and the story missions are mostly of a fairly high quality, unfortunately all the mission in between the story ones are just repeats of the same maps, the same enemies and the same bosses and it gets tiresome rather quickly. The highest difficulty actually succeeds in making the game a challenge although that dissipates somewhat once you start to max out gear and levels around midway through the campaign.

In the multi-player you take control of squads instead but the same RPG elements persist even if they are just included within the map and their effects doesn't persist beyond that. This produces some heavily micromanagement intensive battles which will be interesting for some, dreadful for others. I found myself missing the classic strategy base building quite often and as such the multi-player never really grew on me.

The developers also added in a second style of multi-player that quickly found itself far more popular than the standard match-ups called Last Stand". In this mode you play together with up to three friends each controlling a persistent hero character that earns experience and unlocks equipment after each battle.

Last Stand plays out in an area
date:
you and your 3 companions must survive increasingly tougher waves of enemies being thrown at you while earning score the better you play. That score is at the end of the round turned into experience for your characters.

While Last Stand is essentially a form of action RPG it feels more truer to the style THQ seems to have been aiming for in Dawn of War 2 and as such playing it comes much more naturally to those that do the single-player campaign first. I had a lot of fun in although the matchmaking system and the prevalent lag issues did annoy me quite a bit.

Graphically Dawn of War is a pretty enough looking game and the WH40K art-style works wonders as always. The sounds are as satisfying as ever and the voice-acting is sufficiently competent to keep you in the mood.

It is also worth noting that this is a Games For Windows Live game with all the problems that goes along with it. Don't even bother if you have an unreliable internet connection.

All in all Dawn of War 2 was a game I enjoyed despite it's flaws
recommended: the single-player was fun albeit a bit grindy at times. The regular multi-player was quite dull but the Last Stand mode made up for it
hoursPlayed: when it worked. It's a good game and a good buy

reviewText: A solid spin-off of the traditinal RTS, DoW II takes the premise of a stong first showing with DoW and Winter Assault and takes the game to a whole new level. The single player campaign allows for some solid action and adventuring against a new host of enemies while the new levelling and item equip system establishes some continuity and a more goal-oriented approach than the traditional Build up and tear down" RTS campaign can offer.\n\nRich voice acting and solid graphics couple with the telltale chaotic pumping of bolters
date: plasma guns and chain swords to provide a great visceral experience with great ambiance and enough versatility to allow you to customize your style of play / strategize from mission to mission using different units to suit different approaches.\n\nBest of all
hoursPlayed: Drop out" mission by mission co-op feature to the campaign makes gaming with friends easy and effective. A great buy if you can get Chaos Rising and Retribution in an package for $10 - $20."

reviewText:
Review For Warhammer® 40,000™: Dawn of War® IIReview by: DEHU

Pros :- Great Story
- New Gameplay
- A Good Expansion.

Cons :- 4 hero units for one person is hard without playing Co-op
- A Bad Expansion

Review :Warhammer 40.000: Dawn of War II is a sequel to Warhammer 40.000: Dawn of War, and gives you a new story, with new Characters. The Commander have no real name, only the name you give him.

It starts out with the war against Orcs and Elders, but you will face a greater thread, The tyranids.
The Tyranids are a dinosaur like alien race, with the strategy; Numbers over Strength.

You control only Hero units in the story, The Commander, Tarkus (Normal Marine with 4 in squad), Cyrus(Scout/Sniper with 3 in squad), Avitus(Heavy Weapon with 3 is squad), Thaddeus(Melee Jetpack with 4 in squad) and Gordian(Support).

You play as the Blood Ravens in a war to free the world from The Tyranids and with equipment you can find in the stages and equip after the battle gives the game more depth and with level up system and skill tree, you can make the ultimate team.

The Chaos Rising Expansion, follows up after the war on Tyranids and put you against the Chaos Space Marines.

There is also Retribution. The worse Expansion ever.
You can choose what race you want to play, in the campaign, but the battles are the same, only different Rival.

Warhammer 40.000: Dawn of War II is a pretty well made game with pretty good story, and with the different gamemodes it makes it more fun.

Additional Infomation :Developer:  TRelic Entertainment
Publisher: THQ (Former), Sega (Present)
Genre:  Action, RPG, RTS
Released on Steam: 19. feb 2009

reviewText: Warhammer® 40,000: Dawn of War в свое время был жутко интересной стратегией, с разнообразными расами, интересными юнитами, ну и конечно же, затягивающей и эпичной кампанией. Что бы дать достойный отпор живому игроку, приходилось детально изучать понравившуюся расу, использовать сильные её качества и уметь прикрывать недостатки. В Dawn of War II от стратегии мало что осталось(тупой захват стратегических точек + убить босса), развернуться негде, да и выбор, за кого играть, теперь стал не таким уж большим, Зато графон стал очень приятен глазу, смерти - еще более жестокими(за что мы все и любим эту серию), взрывы техники тоже выглядят очень здорово. reviewText:
Incase you can't tell from the title, Dawn of War II is a Warhammer 40,000 game. If you don't know what that is you better look it up before you think about buying something with Warhammer attached to it,  they are not for everyone .
It is also a Games for Windows Live Game as well as a Steam game, so if you want a game for its' multiplayer look somewhere else. Now... I'm going to break things down into ratings.

Gameplay 9/10
Very strategic strategy game, tactics will get you a lot more than sheer numbers or unit strength.

Single-Player Campaign 10/10
The Dawn of War II campaign is a mix between Horde Survival, plot and a RTS. And I'll be damned if it doesn't do it well. Dawn of War II is quite different from its predecessors. No longer is their extensive Base Building. Infact, in a Campaign mission you have NO BASE. You may have a location, a base you need to defend for a mission but it isn't yours. You can't build stuff from it. There are strategic locations scattered around the mission maps though. Your 'army' is divided into 4 squads. Throughout the campaign you will end up acquiring more than 4 squads but you can only deploy 4 squads to a mission. Each squad is unique, they have their own strategies and skills. The game has introduced a Experience system. This system is most noticeable in the Campaign. As you kill and kill, as well as complete missions your Squads will gain levels individually (to a maximum of level 20). With each level your squads gain two points to put in a talent tree of your choice. Most squads have certain trees that they can put enormous amounts of points and skill into, while others they can only put a few in because of previously stated differences in each Squads specialization. Also, you may chose the 'wargear' for each of your squads. Some of these wargear provide statistic bonuses and similar to the squad that has that item equiped. Others are weapons that will allow the squad to better fulfill a certain task. At the end of the day though, you can have considerable flexibility with you squads. Invest you points in the right talent tree and a Squad that is intended to fulfill 1 role a certain way can fulfill a different role in a different way. Customization is one of the primary elements that has been introduced in force in Dawn of War II compared to its' predecessors. An added bonus is that the Campaign is two player, so you can play through the Campaign with a friend (who has the game obviously). From experience, doing the Campaign in co-op is loads of fun.

Multiplayer 0/10
The Games for Windows Live was a huge hassal, and it was not a hard decision for almost the entire active Dawn of War II playerbase to switch over to Dawn of War II : Retribution. Retribution's multiplayer is through Steam, not Games for Windows Live (thank god).

Graphics 8/10
There are games just as old with better graphics, but that being said... the graphics are certainly not an eyesore.

Audio 9/10
Outstanding voicework all around. Very realistic sounds to be heard on the battlefield. Be it the sound of the last spent shell falling onto the ground or one of you squads talking to each other on the field. Music is good.

All in all, great game but I would only recommend it for Warhammer 40k fans, particularly ones who have somebody to the play the campaign in Co-Op with.

reviewText: I enjoy this game and recommend it for those who are looking for a non-traditional RTS game.  It plays much differently from the first Dawn of War game, which is both a positive and a large negative.  When I first played the game, I was turned off by the fact that it was not like the first game at all, where you could have massive armies facing each other, upgrade your forces, and just summon a slew of Dreadnoughts if things weren't working with your 'subtle' approach.  However, once I examined the game on its own merits, I found that I enjoyed it very much.  You have to be careful with your units and determine what their strengths are (and what you want to be their strengths).\n\nI recommend playing it, at some point, on the hardest difficulty (Primarch).  The loot is better and the strategy aspect of the game becomes much more pronounced than it does on the lower difficulties (where a suicidal assault works because you're awesome).

reviewText:
Dawn of War 2 is a great game.
(for simplicities sake I will include small references to the expansion Chaos rising here)

If you played the original series and loved it, DoW2 is a bit of a departure from the old format but is none the less very enjoyable

Overall -
New mechanics, taken from Company of Heroes, such as a retreat function
More defined rock/paper/scissors
No more base building. In multiplayer you now have one Building from which everything is produced which you can level up through technologies advances
New race - Tyranids (Space dinosaurs)
-races available - Space Marines (super soldiers in space), Orks (they are Orks in space), Eldar (Elves in space) [chaos rising] Chaos Space Marines (Evil Super soldiers in space)

Campagin - quick overview
The campaign (in which you can only play space marines) is now a squadbased/rpg esque series of missions with different characters that you can level up/give different gear to and, in chaos rising, you can corrupt them, turning them to the ruinous powers. The campaign is fun. Missions are often 10-20 minute affairs with varying objectives. The units that you control are powerful and you will smile as 10 Space marines chew through a good 5 tyranids. The campaign is Co-op as well which is fun to play with a friend. Max level for you characters is 20 and chaos rising pushes it up to 30 and adds a couple characters.

Multiplayer - quick overview
In multiplayer, mostly you will be playing matchmaking (though im not sure how much of a community there is so you might be searching for quite a while but if you get it with friends it is still fun) with the sole objective being point control. Resources are gained through capturing requisition points much like in the original DoW. Power is now generated by holding power points and building power generators on it. The four races are all unique and fun each having their own strategies. You can level up all the different races with cosmetic details as you gain experience for games.

Last stand - quick overview
Last stand is where you pick one character, which you can level up to level 20, from one of the 4(5) races (you have access to all of them no DLC unlike in retibution). Then you and 2 other people have to withstand 20 waves of enemies. A simple wave survival game mode but very fun when you get to higher waves and you have to fight 50 space marines with armour shredding plasma guns.

An exceptionally fun game that i have spent far too long playing. The campaign is fun and quite long. The multiplayer is tactical and quick. Games generally don't take hours and combat can be quite intense. Last stand is a wave survival mode where you can laugh manically as you call in an orbital bombardment or fire massive balls of flame at hordes of poor gaunts.

reviewText:
Squad based strategy set in one of the most interesting sci-fi / fantasy universes you will ever come across. Unlike the first dawn of war games it isn't a true base building RTS, base building only partially comes into the game in the retribution expansion.  This is honestly one of my favorite games and along with the chaos rising expansion, the best squad based game i have come across. Although this is largely due to the awesome setting of the 40k setting.

Be very careful when buying this game, it originally came with Games For Windows Live (GFWL) and doesn't work without it. The same goes for Chaos Rising unfortunately. As GFWL is now dead the game does not work (As of 1st of march 2014) and hasn't for several months.
Retribution does work but I found it to be the least interesting of the three games, the campaign involves allot of spamming units and practically no recourse management. It came across to me as some RTS squad hybrid and achieved neither. Not sure about multiplayer in it though could be good.

reviewText:
Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II is a real-time strategy / tactical role-playing video game developed by Relic Entertainment and published by THQ for Microsoft Windows based on the fictional Warhammer 40,000 universe. It is the sequel to the Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War video game series.  Dawn of War II features a non-linear interplanetary campaign, as the Space Marines. The campaign can be played either as single-player or cooperatively with another player through an online connection.

The game's campaign departs from those of its predecessors in several key features. One of the most notable departures is that there are no base-building elements, unlike in previous Dawn of War titles. Instead, the player chooses the units to be used prior to beginning a mission, cannot build new units once the mission begins, and has only limited reinforcement options.

Has several multiplayer modes of play.

reviewText:
Have you always wanted to play real-time strategy games, but you've never been able to handle all of the details? Relic has got your back! They've done a complete 180 from the complexity of Homeworld and, whether through conscious design decisions or forgetfulness on the part of the people making the game, they've left out resource gathering, base building, the cutoff mechanic they pioneered in Company of Heroes, tech trees, control over more than a few units at once, and probably right-clicking (not sure about that last one).

The end result is a game that's perfect for people who love Starcraft, but only a tiny bit, because it only requires a tiny bit of the concentration and skill that Starcraft does. Seriously you can break most of the keys off of your keyboard because you'll need like 8 to play this game.

7 out of 13 SPACE MARINES.

reviewText:
It would have been a much, much better game if the devs had either:
a) used different mechanics that actually fit the franchise, or
b) dropped the WH40k name on it.

As it stands, anyone familiar with the tabletop will be disappointed, because the mechanics don't match the expectations. I've seen squads of 4 eldar guards having more than twice the hitpoints than 4 tactical marines. I've had WoW-style arena boss fights against orcs with 17k hitpoints and the ability to summon flamewaves and earthquakes.

Seriously, I'll pass on this one.

reviewText:

reviewText:
This game is a disgusting joke of a sequel. Dawn of War was an awesome game, and its expansions were really cool. 9 unique races to play? Amazing. There were some balance issues, but the game was really fun and offered so much choice.

reviewText:
I won't rehash what everone else is saying about this game.

The one thing that bothered me was how this game went full WoWtard. Made back in 2009ish, you can smell the chaos taint of WoW all over this crap. How? Each level is a snore fest, which takes about 10 minutes to beat, only to bring you to a boss at the end of each map. And the boss is basically a Raid Boss from WoW, complete with rediculous life meter, dodgable attacks, etc...

So what ends up happening is that you take 10 minutes to get to a boss fight which itself, lasts a boring 10 minutes, as you run around dodge, revivie, heal, etc...

This game is basically a 2.5D single player MMO.

The only time this game gets any cool, is when you finally get Terminator armor at the end of the game, and you get to feel badass. Besides that, go play the original Dawn of War if you want a real RTS experience.

reviewText:
Single player was fine.
Lore is amazing because warhammer 40k lore is amazing

Custom public games I just got teamed with really good people who still actually this MP and got stomp'd.

MP mechanics I did not enjoy

Rock paper scissors unit balance

Not bad overall but ye I really had problems with the MP which is what I tend to enjoy doing most in games.

reviewText: I have always liked the Warhammer series of games, Dawn of war 2 is the exception. I wish they follwed dawn of wars' style. Instead they went with a very boring, controller 4 units game. sure it is great for micro practice but even then it still sucks because in any RTS game i ofter and almost always command more than 4 units. the combat system is ok, its a good reminder of what it used to be. As for story line. i think all warhammer fans think the same way. kill it! it focuses on the space marines, then a latter expansion gives you a choice of race. which is cool but should have been released with the vanilla version. Nothing really pops about this game. after you do 5 missions and meet the eldar you have experienced almost everything the game has to offer, to the point where it feels to much like grinding in an RPG and less like tactical warfare. id give the game a 3/10 and a 4/10 for the latter expansion. i bet if they made a dawn of war 3 and remade the first one they would have a great game, but this... i9 wouldn't give it to anyone. even if they paid me to take it. If you want to play it i will save you some money. go find a rough brick wall, then place your face against the wall and grind your face off till you hit bone. the surgery, pain killers and wasted time in the hospital would be more fun and in the long run would be a better experience than this

reviewText:
Not a member of top-tier RTS games, but a sincere attempt to bring Warhammer 40K to the genre.

The Dawn of War series struggles from one thing more than anything else. It's not Command and Conquer and it's not Starcraft.

If you can accept that, and the extensive expansions you might need to acquire in order to play the preferred race, this game will likely keep you entertained for a number of hours.

I found the campaign to be fine from a story standpoint, but often repetitive and a bit boring when it came to actual game play.

The multiplayer mode was, oddly, lacking some level of immersion. The scale of the battles was quite underwhelming and while the resource acquisition was fine, the objectives were not enough to make up for an experience that was just not very... 40Kish.

I can recommend this game for what it is, a 40K RTS. If you are seeking some RTS experience that immerses you for hours and really give you a new take on the genre, this really isn't the game you are looking for.

reviewText: I wrote several reviews about this game, this is my final. This is not a strict strategy game, its a MOBA+strategy, a hybrid. Its good only for 2v2 and 3v3 and that's what most players of this game play. Its well suited for Faction war meaning all 3 heroes of the same faction together in the same team fighting all the 3 heroes of another faction. Playing the game like that its real fun so for i recommend real life friends to get it as this is how i started this game. Dont get the game if you are to play it solo you wont have fun. It would be great if its campaign had 4 player cooperate instead of 2 so that's a big deal negative, if there is a patch  that makes coop campaign for 4 players that would be great. In general i only recommend to get this game if you have a real life premade team lets say or you plan to play it with online friends, its good for that. Its a minimized CoH 1 but its not Warhammer game. If yougonna play multiplayer DoW 2 Retribution then you MUST get Elite mod, if makes the game real good and balanced. The modding team even fixed bugs retail has. The single player sadly has no 4 player coop mode but 2 which is very bad. DoW 2 Retribution is poorly made mini CoH 1 and has nothing to do with Warhammer 40K. DoW 1 mods are WAY BETTER and are 40K SOLID. To a casual gamer i recommend this game, to someone who wants 40K no i dont. This review is both for DoW 2 and DoW 2 Retribution.

reviewText:
Going to try and make this short...  The game is beautiful, I love how they allowed more factions than in the base game, music is nice and still has some 40k authentic this&that, but sadly it's not feeling like the glove is a good fit this time around.  Was enough of a disappointment I it led to not being able to recommend this game.

I was obviously disappointed.  I will try and make this short and give a few examples, but that's it. Dawn of War was great even though it lacked full customized matches (POP, Unit limitations, in-game map maker, etc...).  I love Space Marine; love painting it, reading it and even played some Tabletop, but too many things missing that should be added or not changed from the original.  A few examples are: Unit grouping (Ctrl+# = unit made and should stay within intelligent proximity = This Technology came out many years ago and easily adjusted) and no more unique buildings ....sucks!  Their attempts to lean into a MOBA are more than obvious to disadvantage.  A moba style will kill this game for me and all I know, so hopefully they do not go that route...hopefully.  They will be hiding under the wings of many successful MOBAs.

I am a diehard 40k fan/gamer and I really wanted to give this game a great review, but I just can't.  Biggest disappointment for me was simply no buildings, but we are all different and that one was mine...

Sirspoony rating: 5/10 ....more buildings and a couple other major changes = 8/10

I will come back again and again to check up on this game and really hope a few more patches and things will feel right once again or maybe even better, but with their obvious direction I think maybe after their MOBA fails...ugh :)


UPDATED REVIEW:

After some dicussion and more exploration in suggested DLC and strategy talks, my review has changed slightly.  I can now recommend this game.  When playing in a team based environment the game can be tons of fun over TS, but without that and trying to PUG, it's still lacking; given how small the community is, among other reasons.  In the end though I granted the game a better rating, but deep down inside I really wanted to find a way to give a recommendation.

NEW Sirspoony Rating:  6.25/10

reviewText:
By far the best RTS game ever.. I cant get enough of the campaign.. Even though i now have to reattain all the achievments again, i dont mind.. DoW2 had many, many missions, and loot.. While DoW2:Chaos Rising added the Librarian, and Choas..

reviewText:
The game has been lifted from the curse of Games For Windows Live due to it's death (Hello death of microsoft, you're looking all too close, yet far away) and because of that, I have returned to rewrite my review.

Currently at the time of writing this review, you can access steamworks enabled server support by going into the Beta tab under the game's properties and clicking on the menu to bring down the beta option, and yeah you get it, you're not a stupid, I don't need to tell how to do it since... well it's already rather obvious to begin with.

I currently have not tried to play multiplayer or The LAst Stand or anything save for he campaign on rare occasion, but i do know that those can't have changed, though I did notice easy AI able to win a game on their own, which surprised me in skirmish... since before their AI was just... so passive when coming to base attacks.

At the moment, with steam achievements being able to actually be earned (giving them an actual reason to exist, it would seem Relic saw GFWL's death coming eh?) and without the stupidity of GFWL itself and all the problems it had, the game is much better.

Much like many other games like Dark Souls and Resident evil Operation Racoon City (the last one not being patched, I'm thinking it won't ever be, what a shame that is), the GFWL interface and networking was the game's largest and highest weakness.

Just know that if you wanna play online with anyone... you absolutely need the DLC as I'm very sure nobody is playing The Last Stand on the original game, aka this one.

The game (this version) has the Tyrannids, Eldar, Orks, Space Marines (It wouldn't be Warhammer anything without those last 3) and... actually that's it.

The game dangles Chaos Rising being needed for the Chaos faction in our faces, but not for Retribution (I'm thinking it'll do that for Retribution once you get Chaos Rising, which is actually kinda intelligently done actually).

The game in my opinion doesn't live up to the wonderful, god-like bliss the past few games had and actually doesn't properly deliver the Tyrannid experience. Ironically enough, they were left out of the first Dawn of War game due to how the Tyrannids Didn't require any of the resources in the game and would work off their own resource" but that sort of thing wasn't supported by the engine.

Guess what the tyrannids use? Requisition and Power

reviewText:
I was skeptical when this game announced that it would only be Gears of War style combat and no strategy. The sequel to the RTS Dawn of War has been turned into an arena combat game along the lines of a MOBA. There is no resource management, no bases to construct, and no squads which are the bedrock of the table-top game on which this series is based.

Admittedly, the single-player campaign has a pretty good story line, as far as game storylines go, and the art design of the Warhammer 40K universe is always great.

Bottom line, if you're looking for a real-time strategy base-building game, this is not that game. If you're okay with losing those aspects, or are a real fan of the source material, then give it a try if it's under $7 USD.

reviewText:
I enjoyed the campaign, especially since it can be played co-op with a friend.  However, very linear, and while it gives the illusion of choice and outcome, none of it makes a difference to the main storyline.  Unlike its predecessors, you can't lose campaign, and replayability is null since it's exactly the same each time.

I didn't have the opportunity to try out other game modes as the multiplayer community is nonexistent at this point.

Also not a fan of being limited to the preset hero units.  Although they are customizable to a degree, it seriously weakens them if you don't stick to their intended playstyle, thus defeating the purpose of customization.  It's a neat idea, but it should have been implemented as an improvement on RTS unit creation rather than completely replacing it.

Fun game for the one shot, but I'm glad I got it on sale, not at all worth full price.

34 hrs on record is because I left it open overnight -- probably got up to get something to drink and didn't come back.

reviewText:
Looking to quench that long needed online warhammer game that so many want? Here you go!

Pros: Dawn of war II is a game that involves you, a force commander of the Blood Ravens space marine chapter doing things for your Chapter (Avoiding spoilers) average space marine stuff right? Wrong. The campaign is a detailed, canon, and fun experience when played alone or with up to one friend and you can never be short of a good mission in the Campaign mode. Multiplayer is largely outdated by Dawn of war II Retributions multiplayer last stand and base multiplayer. Largely due to this you wont find hardly anyone online anymore on this game in particular.

Cons: Sometimes I think of myself as repeating the missions but with diffrent objectives and stuff, although the campaign is good it ends up getting repetitive after a few playthroughs this being my 4th. In co-op campaign game ending bugs on connection and during matches is common, not to mention unresponsiveness to commands.

Verdict: This game is a rock on solid for anyone who loves the Warhammer 40k franchise or just likes to shoot xenos in the name of the Emperor. You will find hours of enjoyment and replayability always wondering what new wargear you can earn again and some diffrent choices mid campaign, and you would be happy with the Co-op system that allows for 1 buddy to share Cyrus, Avitus, You, Thaddeus, and Tarkus with eachother.

reviewText:
I have only one bad point to describe in the game.

Please don't say: choose if never played rts in :recruit difficulty. I had to restart campain since I thought it was to easy even though i just randomly klicked. I now started in normal difficulty: seargant. Wich should be the one evryone should use. I felt like Nah i dont wona achieve al those achievements on such easy difficult :p . So that's why.

Now for the game! -> read first if saving up for difficulty noncense

Realy a fun and dynamic game even in 2016. It's more like a team based rpg fighting hordes of enemies taking cover using skills , items like nades.. etc . And u even have a nice squad that can bomb buildings while being invissible. The interactions are sweet. U can see the enemy trying to shoot u when u trow the detonation bomb to the building. Although you are invissible so they can't hit you ^^ I ended my gameplay for today againt a bossbattle. after boss missions you receive rankings on total enemies killed time and squads alive!

Downside?

Well you cannot replay the missions you did :(

-> be aware I only played 3 hours , but it's on one day .  I feel complete after playing this ! Highly recommended . Can't wait for online play

reviewText:
(This review only covers the singleplayer campaign)

Unlike the first Dawn of War and its expansions, Dawn of War 2 strips away base building and armies and puts you in command of a much smaller force. Aside from a couple of missions, you'll be in control of 4 out of 6 squads of Space Marines - which to me makes them feel more like the elite force and super soldiers they're supposed to be - and you're free to choose which squads you use and what equipment they'll carry. Do you hand your Scout sergeant a sniper rifle or a shotgun? Do you field a Devastator Squad for ranged support and firepower or an Assault Squad to take the fight to the enemy? Combined with RPG elements like skills and loot drops and 3 different enemy factions (Orks, Eldar and Tyranids), I found myself spending an awful amount of time in-between missions deciding what approach to use and loved it.

On the battlefield, gameplay is about positioning and micromanaging your squads and their abilities and accessories (like grenades and turrets). I felt like I spent more time thinking and planning while customizing their loadouts than during battles, but its still great fun. There're main and optional missions and they're quite repetitive, but altering my force composition and loadouts made each deployment feel sufficiently fresh for me.

My only gripe is that the cover system doesn't feel precise enough at times. Sometimes your squad ends up in front of cover instead of safely behind it.

And speaking of cover, DoW 2 has pretty lovely cover destruction.

I'm not sure how much exactly I'd rate DoW 2, but it's at least an 8.6/10 for me.

reviewText:
The good:

+ Loot! Color-coded loot! Feel the thrill of something blue dropping until you realize it is another bad Jetpack.
+ Combat is fun
+ Large selection of gear to collect and customize characters with
+ Graphics are good
+ Ok story

The bad:

- Campaign missions get repetitive really, really fast. Go to point A, kill x, point B, kill y. Kill boss. Rinse and repeat about 30 times. You won the game.
- Cover system is sometimes...well...not working.


Overall, this is a fun, squad-based RTS which does justice to the W40K universe.

reviewText:
How can they destroy this franchise so much?

Dawn of War 1 was the best.

Basebuilding, fortification, strategy. That game had it all.. Why did they remove the one thing that made Dawn of War great? I mean the huge battles are great, but why does a developer remove an insanely good game mechanic??

In my eyes Dawn of War ended with the last expansion of Dawn of War 1.

The only semi-good thing about Dawn of War 2 is the last stand mode.

Please relic, get back to your roots, and make a great Dawn of War 3, please include the basebuilding mechanic, i don't want to have ONE building that creates all troops. I want ALL the buildings.

reviewText: Hammering in roleplaying elements that fail to create a decent roleplaying experience but mess up the RTS part of the game. Most insidious: You get rated at the end of each mission, the better you do, the more experience you get and the better your army becomes. Of course, conversely, if you do poorly, you get less experience, your army will remain a poor show an you will do worse in future missions, too, the perfect vicious cycle.\n\nEDIT: If I am wrong, please comment, I actually hope that I got it wrong and that it still is a decent game.

reviewText:
This game abandons traditional RTS features such as resource management and base building (the two things I hate about RTS) and replaces them with RPG features (leveling and character customization, the two things I like about RPG).

You lead a small team of about 6 heroes, and are only able to bring up to 4 into battle. You tend to be vastly outnumbered, but good use of your abilities will give you the upper hand.

Co-op is where this game shines. You can give control of 1-3 of your heroes to your friend while you focus on your own. And then there's Last Stand, which I gave its own review. Last Stand in Retribution has more units and wargear, but it's still just as fun in Dawn of War II.

reviewText: Given my die-hard love of the original Warhammer seriers, this was a kick in the balls. There are very few games of this stature that I regret buying, but this is at the top of the list. Lots of people love this game and god love 'em, but this is a change of genre that really can kill a series. I prefer the prior format, and the squad-based action doesn't appeal to me. This is the penalty I pay for not reading reviews prior to purchase. Had I know what I was getting, I never would have purchased the game. I found Command and Conquer 4 to be equally disappointing as it changed the fundamental mechanics of the game, as well. Again, shame on me for not reading the reviews. I'm happy for those who love this game, but for someone who's used to the way things were" this really disappoints."

reviewText: THIS IS NOT THE SAME KIND OF RTS LIKE THE ORIGINAL DOW. In DOW1, you would construct buildings, plan our your base and defenses, produce units to meet certain types of resistance, and work to destroy the enemy's base and take over the map. DOW2? Nope. It's a squad-based top-down shooter. I liked the original DOW because I'm a fan of Starcraft and I liked this unique take on traditional RTS games, so when I bought DOW2 thinking they just improved on the original formula, I was extremely disappointed to find that they didn't improve the original forumla, they scraped it to make an entirely new game. This would better off be marketed as a different installment to the Warhammer franchise as opposed to the sequel of Dawn of War.\n\nIs it fun? Yes, but I can't recommend it knowing that people liked DOW1 for what it was and will be expecting DOW2 to be more of that, which it isn't. This is an entirely different kind of game, and if you liked the original, you won't find more of that here.

reviewText:
An amazing addition to the Warhammer franchise.
Even if you don't know anything about the Warhammer universe you can still enjoy this title with ease. In fact, the original Dawn of War game (the version before this one) is what got me into the Warhammer universe.
With good looking graphics, solid RTS gameplay, a story that melds with Warhammer story and extra features not usually found in other RTS games, Dawn of War II is an amazing RTS for both single player and multi-player modes.
Runs flawlessly on just about any modern PC you should defianetly pick-up this game if you like real time strategy titles.
I would give this game a solid 9/10.

It's much more story-driven than the first game and it's expansions, but these are completely different games. Fans of the original may have different opinions, but regardless, I strongly recommend that everyone give this a go.

reviewText:
I dont really know, how I should think about this game. While I played Dawn of War for its multiplayer, and Dark Crusade for its campaign (and multiplayer), Dawn of War 2 is like the two side of a blade.

The campaign was...well...more than great, it was awesome! While you had simple unit progression in Dark Crusade, you had now the control over small squads you were able to level up, skill and equip!
The campaign story itself wasnt that great sadly. The multiplayer is a desaster!

Playing as the Bloodravens again, you have to defend their home system against a big horde of orcs and later tyranids.
The campaign works like a round strategy game, where you equip your squads, control your planets and choose missions based on their urgency, difficulty and reward.
Choosing a mission, the real game begins in RTS style and you have up to four unit groups to control. Every group is lead by a hero unit, that has special abilitys and weapons.

Mostly fighting against overwelming enemy forces, you often have to fight tricky and stealthy, use good tactics and know, how to use your forces abilitys.

With every mission you get XP and items and can specialize your troops on melee or ranged combat, health and ability points. You get new weapons and new equipment, and sometimes gamechanger like the terminator armor, that awesomely upgrades your troops (except the scout of course) and gave me a big wtf with the upgraded Space Marine Stormtroopers, with teleport and big hammers. Awesome!

Having 4 units in every mission but a lot more usable units in your rooster, you can choose, which units you use in a mission, desiding on their abilitys and firepower and the enemys you will face.

Now two things shall be said:

The campaign is theoretically endless. You can play as many missions as you want. No pressure to do the final missions. You just have to hold down the enemys enough to keep the Xenos Infection low.

The whole campaign is coop. Instead of 4 units, each player controls 2. Nothing more to say.


Now the big bad:

Beside the campaign, there wasnt really anything useful left in this game. I tried the multiplayer, but was highly disappointed. Buildings are completely gone in this game. You only have a main building and troops. Confusing, frustrating and totaly not RTS like. I played Dawn of War for a long time and I played Starcraft and Age of Empires 2 and I couldnt get any fun in the Dawn of War 2 multiplayer.

I would like to give this game a good rating for its awesome campaign, but it hasnt much to offer beside it. It is like a HD version of Dawn of War without RTS gameplay. Why not making a complete Shooter out of...wait they already did that and it was awful...

reviewText:
This would be a very good solo game, in fact a great solo game, if it weren't so full of bugs it makes a compost pile look barren.

There is some sort of memory leak which eventually causes the video to stutter at an unplayable rate. It seldom shuts down cleanly, nor does the steam client always recover. This is likely related, as rebooting completely fixes it temporarily.

There are multiple places in the various maps where troops get stuck, and without warning 25% of your team is now useless. When it happens more than once in a mission you end up unable to finish.

This is all made worse because there is no way to restart a mission. The challenge of not being able to replay is great, but when the game itself is this buggy it becomes frustrating, to the point of wondering why you even bothered.

I can usually overlook bugs and other problems when a game shows this much promise, but in this case the promises are empty and I have to give it a thumbs down. Which makes me sad.

reviewText:
When I first started playing Dawn of War 2 I was honestly expecting a re-make of the first game series, but I was pleasantly surprised to find a game that could stand up on its own two feet.

People who were familiar with the first game will remember the slightly bombastic cutscenes with in-game models and overly familiar RTS game play, and on these points DOW 2 innovates. Unlike most RTS games you're not expected to manage buildings, which is appealing. The visuals and voices also al feel well-scripted and satisfyingly re-create the chaos we've come to expect from the battlefield.

However, if you're not a fan of Space Marines you'll probably be disappointed to discover the single player campaign is somewhat frustratingly geared only to this particular race. Furthermore, DOW1 actually attempted to characterise the protagonist through its cutscenes (Including a last minute plot twist that I found truly touching!) and this is where DOW 2 falls down a bit. Nobody has any real emotion aside from heroic anger or angry heroics, the Marines all talk with an irritatingly fake batman voice and the mute protagonist fails to strike any sympathy with me as a player. This is what comes of Games Workshop trying to characterise a race who are all literally clones of one another.

So you'll find the meat of this game (The other 3 races!) in the multiplayer and custom game mode, and this makes for staisfying, if somewhat repetitive, fun. However you should prepare to be screwed around by EA-level connection issues as the game insists you connect to windows live even if you want to play offline, which earlier games managed to do without and adds absolutely nothing to the gameplay. I cannot fathom why anybody felt it needed this feature.

Even though the game is competant in single player and multiplayer scenarios, it just can't marry the two together as seamlessly as Dark Crusade did. So yes it's a good game, but it's just not as rich with variety as Dark Crusade was. I don't see why it would have been impossible to have a DC-style campaign mode with four playable races, or even a multiplayer campaign of the same nature where multiple players fight their campaigns across a planet. So in the end it's not a terrible game, it just feels like it took away features from earlier games that worked, added features nobody wanted, and somehow makes the already characterless Space Marines feel even blander.

reviewText:
As a very casual gamer, I am currently enjoying this. RTS games normally bore me a bit and I haven't really been absorbed by the genre since the old Red Alert/Tiberian Sun games.

I do like that they seem to have cut out all the boring RTS stuff, like base-building. Instead, you get to wander around as a gang and just belt the tar out of Orks. It's very much an all-action RTS, and beginner-friendly for a total n00b like me.

The only downside so far was that I put in a few hours on the demo, to gauge whether or not it was the game for me. After buying the full game, it seemed to wipe my saved game, so I am having to redo a fairly big chunk.

Cool game, with nice vivid graphics and plenty of senseless OTT violence to make it both challenging and fun.

reviewText:
Warhammer 40k Dawn of War 2: is an amazing RTS game with a fun single player campaign, much expanded upon from the original version. While this game excells in its single player version, its multi player has been striped down to building units only, and capturing control points.

Although i love this game, because of its age, this game is really only worth owning if you have a friend to play it against online, or you intend to play its story alone in single player.

I recommend this game to people who love Warhammer games, or RTS fans.


8/10

reviewText: If you're a fan of Warhammer, BUY THIS RIGHT NOW.\n\nDawn of War II is unlike any other strategy game I've ever played. It's go a mix of RTS thinking, small unit tactics, and RPG customization. Your troops are not mindless, faceless, indentical low-poly meat shields. Each squad leader has their unique on-battleifeld skills and off-battlefield personality. You get to know the characters as people and quickly get attached to them. The story is intense and full of twists and turns. But all this cool stuff about plot and character developement wouldn't be worth anything if it didn't have a solid foundation. Fortunately, Dawn of War II DOES have excellent mechanics and gameplay. I never felt like the game was cheating" or that the battles were unfair. If I failed a mission
date: it was always because of my own poor decision. I could indentify the moment things started going wrong and what I did to lead myself there. What this means is that no mission is truly "impossible." Even the hardest
recommended: most crazy-difficult missions are totally doable if you're smart. The flip side of this is that the game will make you WORK to EARN that victory. The game does not spell things out for you
hoursPlayed: hold your hand
voteText: or do much of anything to point you in the right direction. All it gives you is an objective and a team of heavily armed Space Marines--and really
helpfulPercent: what more could you ask for?\n\nI'd recommend this to everyone. It's a straight up good game."

reviewText: Much more RPG than RTS. While this is a WH40K it really doesn't earn the Dawn of War title in my opinion. That doesn't mean I did not like this game, because it is excellent, but if you played the original game and expansions, you should not expect much if any of the feeling from those titles. You get specific characters that represent the various classes to bring with you. That includes a Scout, Terminatior, Trooper, Assault Trooper, and even a Dreadnaught. As you progress through the story mode, you will be able to put points into the abilities of your character as well as equip new equipment. If you like turn based RPGs then you will definitely enjoy this game, if you are expecting more of the original Dawn of War, you may want to skip this one.

reviewText:
If you like small-scale tactical combat, where a battle's outcome is just as much dependant on positioning as it is on unit counters and micro management, you're looking in the right place.  Set in the nightmarish 41st millenium, Dawn of War II brings RPG elements into its single player while the multiplayer is focused on combat; you won't find any base-building or resource gathering here, your ability to purchese units is based on how much territory you control.

Sadly Relic no longer supports this game, but you can still get balance updates and new units by downloading the community made Elite mod.  I also highly recommend getting both the expansions, Chaos Rising and Retribution, which are required to play Elite.

Elite mod website:  http://www.dawnofwar.info/

reviewText: Tied with a few other games as my absolute favorites, I just can't stop coming back to DoW II. Set in the deep, rich, and dark Warhammer 40K Universe sets a wonderful stage for the mechanics to unfold. It's a far cry from the base building, micromanaging sort of RTS IE Starcraft, as well as it's prequel DoW I (which was closer to traditional RTS play). Usually managing four squads at a time, the way you use, equip, and level your squads (led by a hero" unit) add huge amounts of replayability to the single player campaign as you are pitted against "countless billions" (several thousand).\n\nNow that the game is switching over to Steamworks
date: it actually works. And with promises of further support
recommended: I consider this a successfully preserved classic worthy of any RTS gamer's time."

reviewText:
Warhammer 40k DoW II is a moba like twist on the beloved origonal DoW franchise, for some it will be a welcome change, for others a turning point to other games.

As an fan of the old DoW game / expansions i found that this was a wierd yet intriguing change for me, the game focuses less on base building (all you can build is generators and you can upgrade your main base, thats it) and focuses more on the constant exchanging of forces and holding capture points.

For people who are used to the general combat of games like Star Craft II this will be similar to how you DoW II runs with no base building and a focus on controlling points. the big focus for this game is control and managing your units effectivly. this can be appealing to some and off putting for others

so in general i would say if you want the old DoW game then give this a skip, but if you want a Warhammer 40k game similar to Star Craft II then id say go for it


Disclaimer
**i have played Star Craft II, im no pro or anything and i dont know 100% what im talking about so this is just a general view i can give and comparision from to 80+ hours ive played**

reviewText:
Epicness incarnated.
As contemporary as this game is, it is a MUST HAVE, a TRUE CLASSIC. It breached the bounds of modern gaming production, reaching the core, the very soul of what games should be. This is a game out of its time; original, enthralling, mesmerizing, awe-inspiring. All words are short-sighted in describing it because it is more than just a game, it is an experience, it is to live an epic tale with flames and blows to your own skin and wounds to your own flesh.

If this game cost a hundred thousand dollars, I would still buy it.

reviewText: One of the BEST strategy games i've played in a LONG time. If your a fan of tabletop 40K like I am, then i gotta say this is DEFINATELY a must play in my opinion. reviewText: Tied with a few other games as my absolute favorites, I just can't stop coming back to DoW II. Set in the deep, rich, and dark Warhammer 40K Universe sets a wonderful stage for the mechanics to unfold. It's a far cry from the base building, micromanaging sort of RTS IE Starcraft, as well as it's prequel DoW I (which was closer to traditional RTS play). Usually managing four squads at a time, the way you use, equip, and level your squads (led by a hero" unit) add huge amounts of replayability to the single player campaign as you are pitted against "countless billions" (several thousand).\n\nNow that the game is switching over to Steamworks
date: it actually works. And with promises of further support
recommended: I consider this a successfully preserved classic worthy of any RTS gamer's time."

reviewText:
This RTS game with RPG elements is a lot of fun to play! You play as a squad leader of Space Marines, whom if you've played the first DoW games you'd recognise some of them. You then go through the campaign completing the main story arch and doing side missions at the same time, upgrading and levelling up your hero squads as you do. It stays true to the 40K lore and it's a lot of fun controlling and playing as the Space Marines.

However fun this game is, there were a few things that brought it down for me. For starters the Games For Windows Live. It's an unecessary program that got bundled into it and it does make matchmaking more of a pain than necessary. Also the maps get re-used, often. Many battles feels like you've fought them before and, in many cases, you have. This can spoil the fun somewhat.

Online is fun. I highly recommend playing 3 vs 3 due to the team based nature of the game. I recommend this game to RTS fans only if you're looking for something less competitive.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Not really a sequel, but still damn good. Dawn of War II takes some concepts from Dawn of War I and flips them upside down. The two games are essentially two completely different games that borrow from one another liberally, and should be seen as such. Usually when a series attempts such a drastic change, it can result into a inconsistent mess. Certainly, Dawn of War II has its own share of embitter fans who feel somewhat let down by the switch of focus in Dawn of War II. But at its heart, if seen somehow as seperate as Dawn of War I, DoWII is a really great game. Sure, the series does lose some of the intrique and atmosphere of the original. If anything DoWII seems somewhat cookie cutter, at least at first. But give it time you will find that you may appreciate it's unique strengths. Windows live also brings the experience down some, enforcing its absurdly intrusive UI over the game's menus. Also if you are looking for a traditional RTS you may find yourself a bit underwhelmed by DoW II's single player campaign.  One of the cool things this game does is take the focus away from resource gathering and obnoxious base building, and replace it with character development with RPG elements, and loot. In this sense, the game plays more like a dungeon crawler, with each mission acting as something of a quest in which you need to achieve objectives A, B, and C, and obtain such and such loot. Its fun, and addictive. At least this is the campaign. The multiplayer may be more familiar to fans of the series as it takes a more capture and conquer that people loved about the original. All in all, it should be said that this well made, if somewhat a departure from the normal RTS/RPG type game. If you are looking for more Space Marine action, this game and the corresponding expansions will keep you entertained for some time.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Dawn of War II is the ambitious sequel to the largely successful Dawn of War, which spawned an incredible 3 expansions. Instead of riding on the success of the original's fundamental RTS roots, DoW II completely changes the rules, becoming a RTT (tactics) game instead of RTS (strategy). Base building is removed, squads can only reinforce at home, and tactical, destructive cover lies everywhere in each detailed map. This is of course akin to Relic's previous project, Company of Heroes.\n\nWhile many remain divided on the transformation, I believe Dawn of War II is a far deeper and more detailed game because of it. While unfortunately the absurdly large and bloody battles of 40K have been scaled down, the detail is even more impressive and the action is just as visceral, and the destructible environments add to this factor. Perhaps the best addition are the RPG levelling and wargear elements applied to heroes, adding to their grandeur and allowing rich customizability, even in multiplayer.

Gud game tho.
Heresy/10
